speechtext: The House resumed from Tuesday, May 19, consideration of the motion of Mr. Andre that Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada, be now read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: When debate ended, the hon. member had 10 minutes of questions and comments.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday I listened very carefully, as I intend to do throughout a debate that is so important for the future of our country, to the comments made by my hon. friend, colleague and neighbour, who incidentally will celebrate his 25th anniversary as a parliamentarian next Friday, on May 29. He was elected to this House on May 29, 1967, and I thought we should mark this occasion. I listened carefully to what the hon. member had to say, and it brought back a host of memories of all the events around this constitutional question.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
I keep thinking that if we had only ratified the Victoria charter-someday, we will have to write history as it is-we would not be here, rehashing the same subject more than 20 years later. Political observers should take another look at the Victoria charter, in light of the revelations by special advisers who had said, at the time, that Victoria was unacceptable.
I also keep thinking that if we had only ratified Meech Lake, we would not be here discussing the constitutional question once again. In other countries people are killing each other and burning cities and getting into fights about constitutional questions. In Canada, things are different. We talk and talk, and eventually, when we think people are really getting fed up, we finally find a solution, and that is what we will try to do.
I must say that my hon. colleague and friend very aptly expressed-and I speak as chairman of the caucus of Liberal senators and members from Quebec-the wishes of the Quebec caucus in Ottawa, when he said there should be spending limits. We discussed this at length, and I appreciate his emphasis on this point. He also said that this kind of referendum seemed to require a double majority, a majority across Canada and a majority in each of the regions, but, irrespective of the final debate and the ultimate decision made in this House, we will never tolerate imposing a decision on a majority of Quebecers who would be opposed to it. I would not tolerate that, and I know I have colleagues and friends in all parties who would agree this would be entirely unacceptable.
I also urge political observers, colleagues and friends-and I would appreciate the hon. member's comments-to remember that in 1978, just to show there is nothing new under the sun, on April 4, and I am proud to say my memory has not failed me, Marc Lalonde, then minister of state responsible for federal-provincial relations, tabled a referendum bill. Everybody knows Marc Lalonde and I have had a number of vigorous discussions. We often disagreed, but I must say that his presentation on the referendum bill, and I have a summary here of the main provisions of that bill, contains many elements that we also find in the bill before the House today.
In any case, I hope that whatever the tenor of discussions by the party leadership, the government will
agree to accept amendments. I would appreciate it if the hon. member would tell us if we stand any chance of getting through to the responsible minister, who seems determined to argue:

"It's going to be my way or no way." I would like to tell him that it is going to be no way if he thinks it is going to be his way.
On a question of such dramatic importance for the future of our country, I would hope that the government would have the sagacity, the intelligence of accepting major amendments, when the time comes. I would suggest that we should go to committee, not a committee of the whole but I would prefer a committee of this House, to study exactly what this referendum is all about. I would not understand if the political parties did not participate. I could not accept personally if the political parties do not participate together in the drafting of the question. It is unacceptable. I know my colleague is an expert. I am sure he will vigorously defend that point of view expressed by us. He is our representative. We want to participate in the drafting, it should not only done by the government. There should definitely be a limit to the expenses, and there should be fairness for both points of view that will be expressed to Canadians.
I thank him for his views which he expressed yesterday. I trust he will be vigorous in his representation and I would like him to comment further on the few proposals that I just made.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank my colleague from Saint-Denis for his statement. In particular, I must say that it is quite appropriate to set spending limits for the yes and no sides. Without spending limits, the wealthier will obviously have more opportunity to put across their point of view and may be able to impose their opinion in such a way that the others will feel wronged in what must be as democratic an exercise as possible.
May 20, 1992

I find it rather strange that the government refuses to impose spending limits by arguing that under the charter, people cannot be forced to get together under a yes or no umbrella. I would tell those who say that Canada is too diverse to have such umbrella committees that Great Britain used such a procedure in the referendum on its joining the European Community.
When the House adjourned yesterday evening, I was talking about this referendum held in Great Britain. Before I was interrupted, I was going to say that the no camp in Great Britain contained ultra-Conservative unionists from Ulster and Trotskyist coal miners' unions, while the yes camp included the Labour Prime Minister and the English managerial class. Moreover, the yes side included some ministers in the Wilson cabinet and some ministers in the Wilson cabinet were on the no side.
That makes me think of the division of opinion now in the Conservative government. Some days, on seeing the minister of intergovermental affairs say one thing and the minister of health another, one wonders whether these two gentlemen are not preparing to be in different camps in the referendum that might soon be held in Canada. But just because the leader of the Reform Party and the leader of the Bloc Quebecois might be on the same side in the Canadian referendum does not mean that there should be no umbrella committees. On the contrary, I think that it is quite natural, in a referendum on a major issue, to find people of different allegiances on the same side. That was the case in the Quebec referendum.
We will recall that the present leader of the Liberal opposition stood with Camil Samson, leader of the Creditiste Party, and the then leader of the Conservative Party, who today is the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs. These three people, of very different political stripes, were on the same platform, in the same camp, and that did not prevent the referendum from being held and running smoothly.
I bring up these things because it seems to me that the government is hiding behind the charter of rights in its desire not to set spending limits for the principal camps in a referendum. We think that spending limits are absolutely essential and that the government must understand and accept this. There will be no credible, fair,
Government Orders
equitable and democratic referendum unless the spending of the groups that take part in it is limited.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened yesterday to the debate with a good deal of interest. I was perhaps looking for some passion about our country and expecting to see in the House of Commons a sense of co-operation and accommodation in terms of dealing with this very important issue of legislation for a consultative referendum for Canadians.
Unfortunately I did not hear what I was looking for. Just a moment ago when my hon. colleague across the way asked a question of the member who spoke last yesterday I noted that he made some reference as to whether we should have spending controls on the legislation. The answer suggested that we should and that the government is somehow doing something wrong by not imposing these controls.
I have some things I would like to say about this, and I have some references I would like to make. However I would like to begin by quoting an article in The Ottawa Sun today by Michel Gratton.
In response to my colleague he said that the Liberals "obviously want a national plebiscite on the constitution". He also said:
I can understand the opposition's frustration. They are not in control. It must be particularly hard for those Thideau-era Grits who used to manipulate their adversaries in similar fashion. I don't remember Jean Chretien consulting too many opposition members on constitutional matters.
And I don't remember any of them complaining about "no spending limits" on referendum expenses when the Thideau ministers surreptitiously poured millions into TV advertising to defeat Ren6 Levesque's plebiscite in 1980.
I think it ill behoves any of us to say that we have some answers that are rooted in the past or rooted in absolutes when history has proven otherwise.
What is important in this debate is that we examine all the issues carefully and thoughtfully, thinking not only of our own political concerns, our own regional concerns, or our own particular interests. We must examine the issues carefully and thoughtfully in terms of the interests of the country as a whole and at large.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
On the question of the referendum and why we are doing what we are doing in terms of this legislation there are some very straightforward answers that require non-partisan and thoughtful debate in order to arrive at the right conclusion to serve the country as best as we can.
First, there seems to be confusion in the minds of many of our constituents, our audience out there, about why we should hold a referendum, why it is not binding and whether the Constitution can be amended by holding a referendum.
For those who may be a little concerned or a little confused about this matter we cannot amend the Constitution through a referendum. It takes 11 governments, the Parliament of Canada and the legislatures of all 10 provinces, to amend the Constitution. That is the only way it can be done. It can be seven out of ten of those provinces with 50 per cent of the population or some other combination including unanimous consent.
That is what is in the Constitution. The referendum allows us merely to consult with the Canadian public, to get a sense of the direction in which Canadians would like to see us go. It is a reference to the public to ensure that the decisions we are taking in this very important matter, which is of such profound importance to the country, are decisions that are supported by the population in general. We have heard many questions about whether or not the Constitution should have a decision pending on the double minority, majority in all four regions, or a majority in any particular region or any particular province. My answer to that is that if the referendum cannot ultimately amend the Constitution, if it is not binding on the government-and it cannot be because of the way in which the Constitution was amended in 1982-then all the referendum is designed to do is provide a reference point for the decision-makers in the country. Once we have consulted with the country then we will have the kind of direction we need in order to take the next step.
It might be said by some opposition members that this does not demonstrate the kind of leadership that government should be taking on an issue like this. On a question such as this one we need to have as much support for the ultimate decision as we possibly can.
This is not just a question of an election bill, it is not just a question of a budget bill or a matter or policy that affects us in a small way. This is the question of the future of our country. I think that all Canadians are interested in that outcome, regardless of whether the Constitution can be amended by other than the provincial ministers and the Parliament of Canada.
This allows us to consult with Canadians to get their sense of our direction and where we are going. It provides us with the kind of information we need to plot the course of action and take us to the next step so that we can do what everybody wants, which is keep the country together. There is no shame in that. There is no shame in doing absolutely everything that is within our power to keep the country intact.
The other question that continues to arise concerns why there is no limit on the amount of money that can be spent in talking about this question, and saying that people should vote yes or people should vote no. I personally do not know, and I do not understand emotionally or intellectually why anyone would want to do anything to limit the right of individual Canadians to express their opinions on this particular and very important issue.
It seems to me that even if we did not have a Charter of Rights and Freedoms that is very specific on freedom of speech, as Canadians we would want to have that ability to speak loudly and clearly and to be heard as well as we possibly could. In fact, it does say in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which was passed in 1982, under fundamental freedoms in section 2(b): "Everyone has the fundamental freedom: (b) freedom of thought, belief, opinion and expression, including freedom of the press and other media of communication".
That guarantees that Canadians can say what they like to say or what they feel that they must say to help us keep this wonderful country together. It helps to ensure that a referendum will allow for the greatest expression of opinion and provide the best possible sense of direction for the first ministers. It is they who ultimately must come to grips with the problem and help us amend the Constitution in a way that will give Quebec a sense of having a home within Canada and allow it to feel free enough to be able to express itself in the manner that an individual province and the individuals within that prov-
May 20, 1992

ince have the right to do in this particular country of ours, which is a great democracy.
We hear comments about fairness. It is not fair if we do not limit the spending. It is not fair if we do not reduce the amount that can be said on either side of the question. I do not understand that myself.
It seems to me that in this country we have some fundamental obligations, some responsibility as citizens. Whether we are members of the political system, members of the public at large, or members of the media or the business community our first duty is to our country and to ensuring that this great Confederation of ours remains intact.
To do that we must provide an atmosphere in which all the partners in Confederation can feel that they have a home which they belong in, and which they stay in because it provides some warmth, some comfort and some hope for the future for them. It is not something that we can force upon the members of the federation.
If we had a unitary country, I suppose none of this would be happening. It would all be so simple because we would not have to deal with 10 unitary states which have come together in a federation.
But in fact, that is not what we have. We have a great federation made up of 11 partners and two, almost three, territories at this time, that have a sense of individuality. That is appropriate in a country of 27 million people spread thinly across 25 million square miles.
It is difficult to keep a country like this together. The only way we can do it is by allowing each of the members of the federation, each of the partners in this country to have a sense of its own individuality, to express itself according to what is appropriate for its own needs and for its own place in our history and in our country. That is true of British Columbia, it is true of Manitoba, and it is also true of Quebec.
We have come to the pass where some members of the federation feel alienated, feel left out. They feel that somehow the country is not giving them what they thought they were going to get when they first came to Confederation. Therefore, we must rethink our approach to doing things, take a step back, take another look and ask whether there is some better way.
Government Orders
First of all, we have to know that the country wants to stay together. When the committee I co-chaired with Senator Beaudoin, which travelled across the country over the last few months, had completed its deliberations and tabled its report, a poll was conducted by Environics for the Council on Canadian Unity.
It was very clear to us from the results of that poll that, in fact, the one thing a large majority of Canadians can agree on is that they want this country to stay together because 71 per cent of them supported what was in the report. I would be quite surprised if 71 per cent of them actually had all the details of what was in the report at their fingertips.
Even more encouraging about that Environics poll was the fact that 65 per cent of Quebecers supported what was in the report. That tells me also that there is a large sense of wanting to remain in Canada, of wanting to belong to something greater that will lend strength to all parts of Quebec as well as the rest of Canada.
A referendum will allow us to get a sense of direction from every comer of the country, from each of the individual parts. However, we have to be extremely careful that we manage this referendum in a way that will not create alienation in any of the parts.
It would be unfortunate if we were to isolate any part of the federation by drawing very hard lines in the sand saying that there must be a majority here and there must be a majority there so that there is a binding decision. That is not the exercise.
The exercise is to consult, to think and then to determine the next step in a thoughtful way that does what it can to use the information we obtain by holding the referendum to bind the country together rather than use it in a way that might ultimately have just the opposite effect.
I want to say again that the Constitution cannot be amended by holding a referendum. The only way the Constitution can be amended is through the consent of the legislatures of the country, of the 10 provinces and the Parliament of Canada.
In the case of most of the issues that are on the table right now and later between the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and the first ministers, most of those issues can be settled by seven provinces with 50 per cent of the population and the Parliament of Canada

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
consenting. One or two issues, such as amending the amending formula itself, require unanimous consent.
It is important that all members of this House and all people in Canada understand that if a referendum is held, it is a matter of reference. It is a matter of governments and all members of Parliament seeking direction to do one thing and that is to keep the country together. In spite of our own particular political stripe or particular partisan bent, we are all bound together by that same, individual, single goal. If we do not keep this country together, there will not be a Parliament, a referendum, or podiums for people to take partisan positions.
As the debate continues, I hope all members of Parliament will put their country first, put their partisan and personal interests aside just for a moment. Members should work toward a solution that will keep the country together, give all parts of the federation a sense of participation that will avoid any kind of divisive action that would alienate any more parts of the country. I appreciate the opportunity to say these few words today.

I have a question for my colleague, the former chair of our parliamentary committee. It seems only a few days ago we were doing this in the committee, over that five or six month period.
I would like to ask her about the idea people have that in this bill there should be the concept of regional majorities. I know she was not on the amending formula committee which was co-chaired by her friend the senator and the member for Edmonton Southwest.
In that particular committee we had a unanimous report in terms of a consultative referendum. In that referendum wording we said we should have a double majority. We said that if there is a referendum: "The referendum should require a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions: Ontario, Quebec, the Atlantic, and the west".
How would we interpret the results of a referendum if indeed we do not have that in the bill? Would she agree for example that before we proceed with amending the Constitution we would have to have the support of the population of Quebec? If she agrees to that, would she not also agree that we would have to have the support of western Canadians, Ontarians, or Atlantic Canadians?
I have always been of the view that before we can change the Constitution we have to have the support of an overwhelming majority of Canadians. It is not just an ordinary law; it is a very special document, it is the basic law of the country.
If we do not have the four regional vetoes in there in terms of a double majority, what advice would she have as to how we should interpret the results of that referendum?
There are all kinds of results. I would not want to speculate what they might be. I know the Prime Minister may be making a statement later as to how he would interpret the results of the referendum, but I want to know what advice she may have for the House as to how we should interpret those results?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for the question. It is a valid one.
I do not think it is really a question of deciding at this point in time how we would interpret the results of the referendum or try to predetermine what we might actually see when a referendum is held.
It is very important, as I said before, to be flexible enough in terms of the consultation process with the public to allow for that determination to take place when we see the results.
Right now, if we draw hard lines in the sand and take positions and say that we must have a majority in Quebec, we must have a majority in Ontario, we must have a majority from the regions, then we are already asking for resistance and that will reduce the impact and the overall importance of this consultation process we are going through.
If we must go through it, it is extremely important that we be veiy careful that we do not do it in a way that will create some sense of alienation or some sense of isolation in any of the individual parts of the federation.
The hon. member mentioned he was on the Beau-doin-Edwards committee. I know he played a very important role there. There was unanimous consent about the regional vetoes and the double majority. But he will also recall that met with a very sharp rejection by those regions. Therefore, it is one of the questions we have to answer and one of the reasons we have to go so carefully.
May 20, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it should be noted that the hon. member's riding and mine are separated only by the Assiniboine River. I always take note of what the hon. member says. I certainly share her love of country and support her patriotic remarks on behalf of this great country.
I am wondering whether the remarks she made this afternoon are perhaps better suited for the referendum debate itself, if we ever get to that, if the government does call a referendum, and we have to debate exactly what the question is. I say that only because I think that the previous speaker, at least today, should be concerned more with the mechanics of the referendum.
That brings me to the issue of a double majority. Our party believes strongly in a double majority provision in any referendum.
Let me attack it from this perspective. We are all minorities. One way or another, we are all minorities. There are only 295 members of Parliament in Canada and as a body of people, we are a minority in Canada. I come from the province of Manitoba, as does the hon. member for Winnipeg South. In the context of Canada, we are a minority. The people of Quebec are a minority in the context of Canada. Canadians, even though there are 27 million, are a minority in the context of the whole continent. When it comes to North Americans, we are a minority.
I raise that because one of the strong arguments against referenda for a long, long time has been the fear that referenda can be used by majorities to trample on the rights of minorities. That has always been the concern of having referenda. I can relate to that argument. I always fear when people talk about referenda that the instrument can be used by the majority to trample on minorities.
With that concern and with that fear, it leads me and my colleagues on this side of the House to support a double majority. That is the very provision in a referendum that will protect minorities in this country.
We in the west are a minority. We do not want a majority of Canadians to gang up on us when it comes to reshaping the Constitution. I am quite sure that Quebecers feel the same way. They do not want Ontarians or
Government Orders
people from Atlantic Canada or the west ganging up on them.
So how do we protect Quebecers? How do we protect people from western Canada? How do we protect people from Ontario? Even though there are nine million, in the context of the country they are a minority. I cannot think of a better way to protect minorities in this country in a referendum than to incorporate a double majority provision.
I would like my hon. friend from Winnipeg South to comment on that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague and my neighbour for his very good question. There is nothing to say that ultimately, when we see the results of the referendum, it may not be one of the considerations.
Obviously it is in the government's interest to protect everybody in Canada and that is very difficult. That is one of the reasons we have been so reluctant to enter into this whole issue of having a referendum. Clearly there are some downsides to it and it is still a big if.
What we are presenting here today is the ability to hold a referendum. It does not carry with it a guarantee that that is what will happen. By happy chance, if we can come to a consensus, which is really the only fair way that protects all minorities, about how to keep this country together, then a referendum need not be held. If one were held it would only be a matter of rubberstamping what had already been achieved through consensus.
I respect and appreciate the hon. member's question. It is a difficult one. That is why it is so important not to draw too many hard lines or tight rules around how we will or might interpret the results of a referendum, if indeed we absolutely have to have one at some point in time.

Mr. Speaker, I think it is clear the government has failed to consider the impact of its decision to ask the House to adopt this bill and its decision to hold a Canadian referendum in circumstances the government may be said to have created.
Today, May 20, is the 12th anniversary of the 1980 referendum in Quebec.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
My point is that we know what a referendum is like, and we know how traumatic it can be. We have seen the consequences and we are keenly aware of the political and democratic requisites for the referendum process. It so happens that the referendum that may be held as soon as the bill before the House is passed does not meet these criteria, Mr. Speaker. It does not meet the criteria for political legitimacy, because to us in Quebec, it is not legitimate. And as for being democratic, as far as Canada is concerned, it is not.
When I say it is not legitimate, I mean that the motives behind the government's action are patently suspect and extremely negative. It is painfully obvious that its real purpose is to do an end run around the referendum Quebec is about to call itself. After two years of dilatory measures, of successive failures of initiatives like the Spicer commission that turned into a regular circus, the proposals tabled on September 24, 1991, which were practically stillborn, the Beaudoin-Dobbie report which has now been shelved after only a few weeks, it seems as though this government all of a sudden wanted to prevent Quebec from holding its own referendum.
Why? It so happens that for the past two years a major movement has been growing and taking shape in Quebec, leading to the rebirth of the sovereignist movement. Whether we like it or not, Mr. Speaker, at the heart of the Canadian malaise and our political landscape, the major issue is Quebec's sovereignty. We can talk until the cows come home, we can waste our time on contitu-tional commas and semi-colons, we can use increasingly convoluted formulas to dilute the distinct identity of Quebec, but basically, we are just trying to evade the real issue. The real issue is: Will Quebec become sovereign, yes or no? In any case, that is what Quebecers have on their minds. I am not saying everyone will say yes, but in Quebec there are a lot of people who think Quebec should become sovereign and who want to be able to answer a question dealing with this particular subject. And this led to a commission of inquiry known as the Belanger-Campeau commission, which sat for nearly one year. Three members of this House sat on the commission, and I was one of those members. This commission, whose members represented all activity sectors in Quebec, including labour, business, communities and all political parties, reached certain conclusions. Of course it could not reach a consensus on sovereignty or federalism, but there was one conclusion on which we all agreed and that was the enormous cost to all of us, in Quebec and Canada, as a result of the uncertainty in this
country, an economic cost that is impossible to assess, a financial cost as well as a social cost and political cost.
Our society is not preparing for the major challenges of the future. While the world is busy building and rebuilding, Quebec and Canada are playing these introspective games. We have an education system that has to be renewed. We have to develop new technologies. We must redesign our national fabric, in Canada and Quebec, and meanwhile we are wasting our time on an endless discussion which contributes nothing to this debate. Why? Because some people, and these are mostly politicians or governments, do not want Quebecers to say what they want. But until Quebecers have voted in a Quebec referendum held under the auspices of the State of Quebec, by answering a question that deals with sovereignty, and until a decision is made, nothing will be settled.
Anything done by this government under siege, which is trying to use a referendum as an election platform and wrapping itself in the Canadian flag to save its own skin, will be useless. It is not getting us anywhere, and since this referendum is not legitimate because it does not answer the real question, because it will not resolve the real problems, the Bloc Quebecois will never feel bound by the results. Never. We will just be back to square one.
We are well aware that this referendum which the present government is preparing to hold is also an act of impotence, an admission that its own efforts have failed. This government had promised to make an offer to Quebec. Quebecers know that the political situation may produce an offer of renewal or lead to sovereignty. The Belanger-Campeau commission concluded that Quebecers, like Canadians, by the way, had two options: sovereignty for Quebec or thoroughly renewed federalism. Supposing federalism can be renewed and that an offer might still come from the federal and provincial governments, the Government of Quebec created a parliamentary committee to study any offers that might come and would be binding on the federal and provincial governments.
May 20, 1992

This government had the obligation to make an offer, but it failed every time it tried to come up with one. So when the government tells us now that it will hold a referendum, what is it saying? It is telling us to forget about offers. Forget about the discussions going on in Montreal today and that have been going on throughout the country for some time. This government has two strategies. There is the strategy of the minister responsible for the issue, which is to try to come up with an agreement, and the strategy of the Prime Minister, who has concluded that the negotiations would fail.
By preparing to hold a referendum, Mr. Speaker, he is telling us: "The current negotiations are a farce. I know that my minister responsible is a naive man who is wasting his time and wasting the country's time. In fact, this country needs something to stir up the electorate, so that I can then hold an election on the basis of a yes vote that I will get on a phoney question." That is what is going on, Mr. Speaker. Let us be logical and open our eyes.
While we are wasting our time on what is supposedly a referendum debate, we are just discussing a life buoy that this government, which is dangerously adrift, wants thrown to it.
We in the Bloc Quebecois will not go along and take as hypocritical a stand as some others. I was there the other day when the Leader of the Official Opposition tore his shirt on learning that the bill would be tabled. He denounced its undemocratic character and added shortly afterward that he would vote for the bill, even without amendment, regardless. What inconsistency. That shows the government's tricks and the opposition's inconsistency. Inconsistency is a kind word; why not use another word that is in the dictionary, but I do not know if it is parliamentary: "hypocrisy". This same Leader of the Opposition tells us-and the hon. member just reminded him-that we should use the democratic rules provided in Quebec's legislation, rules that he speaks of with admiration today, rules that allow fairness in public funding for both sides. What a wonderful law. What a wonderful democratic requirement Quebec has. We should apply it to the federal government. But that same Leader of the Opposition, who was a minister in the Liberal government during the 1980 referendum that we are celebrating today, was determined to systemati-
Govemment Orders
cally violate Quebec's democratic legislation by tipping the scales with money and unlimited federal spending.
This makes me draw a parallel with the present bill. When I just said-and this is my second point-that this bill is not democratic, I believe that the argument may apply to all of Canada. I am a sovereigntist, but not because I believe that the federal government or the federal state is undemocratic. I am one of those who believe that, whatever the future of Quebec, whatever path it takes, it must maintain the democratic institutions that we have lived with for over a hundred years. I am one of those who are generally proud of the democratic tradition under which Canada operates, despite its shortcomings and weaknesses that we denounce from time to time but that in general do not break the continuity of this country's democracy.
I say that this referendum is an infringement on Canadian democracy and if ever a referendum were held in such conditions, it will be a scar on Canada's history and sully a very fine tradition that will always be an inspiration to Quebec. Why do I say that? It is, for example, because of the issue of unlimited spendings.
In every country of the world, at least in democratic countries and especially in ours, there is a requirement when an election is held, because it is an important decision, to put a ceiling on expenses and to ensure that one party will not be able to spend more than another. It is an old rule that has always prevailed. Elections have been held in Canada since the charter of rights came into effect. Nobody ever disputed that rule and I am convinced-this is a legal opinion which is worth what the others are worth and probably less-that the Supreme Court will never allow the law of the jungle to prevail, it will never substitute the power of money for the power of citizens when what is at stake is an issue as important as the future of a country.
Yet the government tells us that there will be no ceiling on expenses. Today I heard in the hallway-I do not know if it is worth anything, I have not seen the text-that the government leader intends to impose a very strict limit on the expenses of each committee, but that he would not limit the number of committees. This is a joke. This is the kind of amendment to be expected from this government. I can just see them show up tomorrow and tell us that they are generous and that they have listened to the voice of democracy. Mr. Speaker, they will come and tell us that they have

May 20,1992
Government Orders
decided to impose a limit on the expenses of the committees. However, they will not limit the number of committees. There can be as many committees as there are Canadians. This is another joke by this government.
What is more serious, even though it often goes unnoticed, is the fact that the government itself, in its management of public resources, will not be subjected to any spending limit regarding the referendum. In other words, ministers will travel in Challenger aircrafts, civil servants will criss-cross the country during the referendum campaign, and they will be able to do just about anything with the government's money, the taxpayers' money, to influence the outcome of this exercise. Officially, it might be true that no party in this House will have access to public funds, but in fact one party will have such access.
This legislation enables the government and the government party, namely the Conservative Party, to use without any restriction, as that government likes to do given the deficit that we have, the public funds, the taxpayers' money, to come out a winner.
Mr. Speaker, if this is the kind of country in which Canadians want to live, the kind of referendum that they want to hold, and the kind of public administration that they want, fine, but us Quebecers say no and this referendum is null and void even before it is held. I can tell you that we will fight it everywhere in Quebec; we will challenge not only the question, but also the admissibility of the referendum, its anti-democratic character, and we will ask the people to vote against such an anti-democratic measure. I can assure you that there will be federalists from Quebec who will vote against the question because they feel that this intervention is shameful, unacceptable, and it goes against their idea of a fair and equitable society.
I have one last point regarding the content of this legislation. It is the issue of majority. Mr. Speaker, we all know that the motto of Quebec is "Je me souviens" and there is a date in the recent history of Quebec as well as in the recent history of Canada that nobody talks about; I am referring to 1942. Let us not forget that the conscription in 1942 was one event that tore the country. The general feeling of Quebecers then, which has been
transmitted from generation to generation since, is that Quebec was the victim of steamroller tactics in 1942. The federal government then used the Canadian majority to bury the Quebec minority, even if our province was opposed to the conscription.
Consequently, we all believed that this government, when it would resort to a referendum and pass the required legislation, would allow for a double majority. I believe several members of the government said so before, to free themselves from the syndrome of 42, the conscription syndrome. But no, Mr. Speaker, there is no end to their excesses because they are in a state of utter confusion and helplessness.
Now, there will be only one majority. Some will claim, on the evening of the referendum, that Canada has decided that yes we had to go ahead by approving the empty question that Canadians will be asked, even if Quebec is a minority as regards the result of that referendum. Indeed, the legislation does not officially provide for any other interpretation than the global result for the whole country.
There is already in there a negation of the principle of the existence of the Quebec people. There is a fundamental negation of the right of Quebec to self-determination, which is a principle that last year, in August, this government mocked when, for publicity reasons, the few thousand militants that had gathered in Toronto to boast about having recognized the right of Quebec to self-determination, walked singing "O Canada" and hugging each other. This is the same party today that tables a bill which negates, in its essence and foundation, the principle that it recognized in Toronto last year.
We can only conclude, regarding this government, that a verdict will be necessary. There is of course an artificial majority here, which does not reflect in any way, as we know, what people in Quebec and in Canada think. The verdict will be a general election. Those people across the floor are all about to be evaluated by the population. That is why they wait as long as they can, that is why they will go to the very end of the five-year period provided by the Constitution. That is why they do not dare come before the population; that is why they hide behind an artificial situation which prevents them from getting the
May 20, 1992

sentence that they deserve. Mr. Speaker, we are ready. A decision will have to be made.
My second and last conclusion concerns the Government of Quebec. We have in Quebec a government whose premier has, because of historical continuity, the obligation of preserving the fundamental prerogatives of the state of Quebec. The first responsibility of the Premier of Quebec is not to be a party leader or to tiy to regain power or to remain in power: It is to ensure that the fundamental rights of Quebecers and of the Quebec nation are preserved. The first of those fundamental rights is of course the right to decide in Quebec, Quebec's future.
This same premier ratified the report of the Belanger-Campeau commission which says that there must be a legislation requiring the government to hold a referendum on sovereignty in October 1992 at the latest. The same premier had the National Assembly pass a bill that contains precisely that conclusion and that requirement. We must demand from that premier, and this is what we expect from him, that he does not watch the federal parade at a time when the presence of the state of Quebec is required in a fundamental and essential way.
Therefore, we believe that if English-speaking Canadians want a referendum, which is legitimate, to define the kind of country that they want, the kind of offers that they would like to make to Quebec, so be it. It is totally legitimate, provided it is done in a democratic way. But at the same time, the central issue must be resolved and it must be resolved only by the logical decision-makers, the legitimate decision-makers, namely the people of Quebec. Otherwise, Mr. Speaker, the steamroller is put into action once again.
I promise you that a great number of members of the Bloc Quebecois will be here, maybe a little farther from the curtain than we are now, with more seats, to again defend the cause of Quebec and to resume a debate that costs a lot to everybody, solves nothing and only makes the situation worse. I call upon realism, I call upon political courage, I call upon the need to make the real decision, which is to decide whether Quebec will or will not be a sovereign state. Leave it to the people of Quebec to decide.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to ask the member for Lac-Saint-Jean a question.
Once upon a time, there was another Quebec separatist who was a democrat. His name was Rene Levesque. I heard the speech of the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean who claims to favour a referendum within Quebec, but not a referendum across the country. Does the hon. member favour democracy in Quebec but not across Canada? That is my question.

Mr. Speaker, the decision Quebecers will be asked to make in the referendum is complex, but one of its elements is quite straightforward. Is Quebec a sovereign nation whose aspirations will be embodied in a sovereign state? That is a fundamental question that cannot be left up to others to decide. Outsiders cannot decide whether or not Quebec will be sovereign. According to the basic principles of democracy, this referendum, which will determine the future of the people of Quebec, must be held under the auspices of the state of Quebec. It only stands to reason. We must not forget that the word democracy contains the word "demos", the Greek word for "people". Democracy is power exercised by the people, which is as it should be. The power at issue here is the power to determine the future of a people, in this case, the people of Quebec.
Basically, the hon. member and I disagree, not on the concept of democracy but on the identity of the people in question. My hon. friend believes there is one people, the Canadian people, while I believe there are two peoples, who will not go their separate ways because they hate each other but because they are fundamentally different, because they have entirely different concepts of what their future should be and of their collective values, political structures and the kind of government they want.
My hon. friend believes that the federal system is a good system for governing this entity called Canada. I say they cannot be administered together, because the people of Quebec want a weak central government and a strong state of Quebec. My hon. friend believes that under a federal system, the central government must be able to govern, and he is right. But it so happens that since we are two peoples, there is one too many in Canada. Or there is one missing, depending on one's

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
perception. To us, what is missing is the Quebec nation, which we must create.

Mr. Speaker, my question for the member for Lac-Saint-Jean has to do with our responsibility as members of Parliament who, when we come to this Chamber, are given a mandate to speak for Canada.
I do not speak just for Toronto. I do not speak here for Ontario. We try to the best of our ability when we are here not just to speak for our own ridings, but we try to work on behalf of the whole country.
When the member was giving his speech, he talked about the fact that the government would be using taxpayers' resources to try and keep this country together.
Does the member think it is wrong for those of us who want to keep the country together, even though we may have a different view of the direction of the country? Does he not think it is our responsibility and duty to the best of our ability to try and keep this country together? If we did not do that, our constituents would wonder what we are doing in this room.

Mr. Speaker, I think with my hon. friend that in a normal federal system when the members are elected in their ridings they must abide by a fundamental duty of protecting the integrity of the country. He is right on that.
We were elected in Quebec. We were elected-that was my case-in a situation where we thought that the Meech Lake Accord would be ratified and that, basing our hopes on this, it would be possible after that, because there would be a climate of generosity and tolerance, to strike a new deal defining the different responsibilities and attributions of Quebec and Canada within the federation.
Meech failed. Meech was rejected and it changed everything. It showed that there were fundamental differences in this country. It showed that a member coming from a Quebec riding would be always obliged to defend Quebec first. It showed that we could not be here as sovereignists forever, that we must be here only the
time it takes to achieve sovereignty, that there would be members acting as members in the House of Commons who would have to defend the country, their country which would be English Canada, and that we would be or other people would be in the parliament of Quebec.
It is a very particular juncture, a transitional juncture where we have to resolve the crisis. We happen to be here. We will seek an additional mandate to come back here with a large number of people, believe me, to complete the job we have undertaken, which is to apply a political solution to a political problem.
Whatever you say, you might wish this to be a unique country, one country, Canada, but it happens that it is two countries, two political entities. We Quebecers feel that we are a people. We have different views of the kind of government we need to be governed, and we think that it can only be achieved through sovereignty and two political structures: neighbours acting in the fulfilment of their aspirations remembering that they have geographical, economic and historical bounds.
Personally I think that we will always be friendly countries, that we are doomed to be friendly to achieve some kind of agreement on the common things we have to do together, but first it goes through sovereignty of Quebec and then maybe something would be possible.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. colleague mentioned the Toronto convention, where it seems that the Conservative Party first recognized Quebec's right to self-determination. I would simply remind him that in Toronto, our party just reiterated Quebec's right to self-determination, since that right had been recognized in 1980. I think that he should remember it, because at that time he was working for the other side on the Quebec referendum. I also took part in the Quebec referendum.
On what side?
I was on the no side, and I have never been ashamed of it.
It's been quite a change.

Mr. Speaker, he said in his speech that the referendum was undemocratic. I have a lot of trouble understanding someone saying that a referendum is
May 20, 1992

undemocratic when it is Canada-wide, but that the Quebec referendum was democratic.
I think that holding a referendum in Canada in no way takes away the right of French-speaking Canadians who live in Quebec to express themselves on the federal government's offers. I think that there is nothing wrong, reprehensible or undemocratic about that and it in no way takes away the Quebec government's right to use Bill 150, which we respect.
So I do not see how my friend opposite can say to us today- He should remember, Mr. Speaker, that not so long ago, he represented Canada in Paris and was proud of it. He said that Canada was the greatest defender of rights and freedoms in the world and an example to follow. Today he tells us in front of everyone here in this House that holding a national referendum is undemocratic. I would like him to explain that to me.

Mr. Speaker, I do not have time to answer the very vicious personal attacks to which I am accustomed. I already did so and will do so at the appropriate time and place, but I want to return to the essential point-
Well, it's very hard to get through to the hon. member.

-which challenged the use of the term "undemocratic" that I used to describe the bill and a referendum that would be held in the context of the circumstances he mentioned.
In fact, Mr. Speaker, it is elementary. As sure as can be, this bill is undemocratic. It is not undemocratic because it asks Quebecers to vote; it is illegitimate, which is even worse.
It is undemocratic because it contains no spending limit and will let our friends opposite go and see business people, engineers, architects, banks, big companies, government suppliers to contribute in order to influence the debate and load the dice. Will this government dare to do the same? We know very well that it will not. It has the impudence and the indecency-A member from

Quebec in this House has the nerve to accuse Quebec of not being democratic when it set an example for Canada and the federal government, which it should follow today, of respecting both sides.

Mr. Speaker, the leader of the Bloc Quebecois and member for Lac-Saint-Jean was just saying that, on this day, 12 years ago, on May 20 1980, the people of Quebec were voting in the Quebec referendum. I was listening earlier, Mr. Speaker, to the hon. member for Portneuf who stated he was on the no side. So was I, along with the Chretiens, Mulroneys and Ryans. I was indeed, and I was looking forward to this renewed federalism which rejected Quebec in 1981. Today, I wonder and I would like to put the question to the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean. Nearly two years have gone by since the failure of Meech, on June 23, 1990. In a month or so, two years will have been spent in this House debating the issue and striking committees to try and resolve the constitutional deadlock we are in. I would like to ask the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean about the statement the Minister of Labour made the other day to the effect that a Canadawide referendum would have no legal value. Would that not tend to prove that the government is afraid of the results of such a referendum? Would it not tend to prove also that it is only a diversionary tactic aimed at confusing people, especially the people of Quebec?

Mr. Speaker, I think the question is relevant and stresses the blatant vagueness of the referendum because they are trying to have it both ways. That is the kind of language we have grown accustomed to with this government. I am not as good at it as I was two years ago. At any rate, it is obvious that this government is talking from both sides of its mouth. On the one hand, it is telling us that the referendum will change absolutely nothing, that it will be meaningless. On the other hand, when the results will be out, it will want to base its future course of action on these results. I think that it fools no one, and I thank the hon. member for this great question.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
I would like to bring to the attention of the House that we are now, under Standing Order 74, in the 10-minute period with no questions or comments.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, today's debate represents one of the most important principles of a democracy. We are here to debate the framework within which the people of Canada will be able to decide their future. Canadians must be able to chart their own course. They must be able to be completely certain that their wishes, as expressed in a national referendum, will be respected.

Mr. Speaker, we must recognize the fact that the Constitution belongs to the Canadian people. It does not belong to politicians or bureaucrats. We must give Canadians a chance to have the last word on any proposal for constitutional reform.
A Canadian referendum would give Canadian citizens outside Quebec a chance to say yes to Quebec and give Quebecers a chance to say yes to Canada. All Canadians must be able to say yes, not just those who live in Quebec or in provinces that plan to hold their own referendums.

We must trust the people of Canada. We must give them final say on any new constitutional agreement. That is why I welcome any legislation that will enable the people of Canada to do so.

Mr. Speaker, the bill gives the government the right to decide whether it is appropriate to hold a referendum, while the Liberal Party believes it is essential for Canadians to approve the proposals for constitutional reform in a referendum.

When Canadians go to the polls to express how they feel about the Constitution, they must have a sense that they will be listened to. They have to believe that the ballot they cast represents a real and fundamental contribution to the future of this nation. To do anything less I believe is a betrayal of the democratic process.
I understand that there are entrenched legal and constitutional mechanisms for the amendment of the Constitution. I know that in order to change some clauses of the Constitution we need to have the co-operation of the federal government and seven out of ten provinces representing at least 50 per cent of the
population and absolute unanimity for others. Despite these facts, we have to recognize that a Constitution has to represent the people that it is intended to govern.
If we want to address the problems that our society does face, we have to put the debate over distinct societies, Senate seats and various clauses and permutations to an end. I know that the people of Canada will take advantage of a national referendum to put this issue to rest.
The process that the government has put into place is flawed. I believe that the largest and most fundamental flaw is that the government is not committed to respect the results of the referendum. Not only must its commitment respect the wishes of the entire nation; it must take into account the regional divisions of Canada.

Proposals for constitutional reform should not only require the approval of the people of Canada as a whole, but should also be supported by a majority of the population in each of Canada's major regions, including Quebec. The Prime Minister, however, has refused to promise to give up any constitutional agreement that did not receive the support of all Canada's regions.

We are a federation. We have prided ourselves on balancing the interests of different regions of this country. This must be reflected in this legislation. I hope the government will consider certain amendments that will make the process morally binding at least on the leaders of this country.

Mr. Speaker, we must avoid even the remotest chance that any part of our country might be excluded from the constitutional renewal process.
The referendum legislation must recognize that each region in our country should be comfortable with the new constitutional proposals.

We are not here to accommodate the interests of a few. We are here to make sure that all Canadians, no matter where they live, feel that they are part of the process and are part of the solution. If we are to reach a true national reconciliation, all parts of Canada must be
May 20, 1992

satisfied that their interests are protected in the new Constitution.
Another one of the glaring flaws in this legislation is the fact that there are no spending limits. What in effect this bill enables governments to do is spend unlimited amounts of public tax dollars on the positions they take. The potential exists that taxpayers could be financing both sides of the referendum question with an unlimited amount of money.
During the last federal election Canadians were bombarded with propaganda from third parties on the merits of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. Millions of dollars were spent by big business while few could afford to meet this advertising onslaught. We need to set maximum spending limits and targets so that this exercise is truly democratic.
I know that some members opposite will say that they cannot limit the amount of money that third parties spend during things like referenda. They feel they will be challenged before the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the legislation. They are afraid that the judges of the Supreme Court would see such a limitation as a violation of the free speech provisions of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. No one is saying that we must prevent organizations or individuals from expressing how they feel about a potential referendum question.
The first section of Canada's Charter of Rights and Freedoms says quite explicitly that government can set limits to these rights as long as they are reasonable in a free and democratic society.
I believe that by setting these types of limits on spending, we will be contributing to the democratic process rather than detracting from it. Bill C-81 should facilitate a fair and open debate over the future of Canada and enable the people of this country to have their say through a referendum that will, at the very least, be morally binding on the government.
This bill must stipulate that all regions of the country must have a say in how the constitutional issue will be resolved. That means we need a truly national referendum. I know, for example, in my province of Quebec we will be having a referendum in the coming months. I am also aware that several other provinces have expressed an interest in holding referendums on the Constitution.

What will this patchwork result in? No one really knows. But the Canadian people also have the right to respond to a national question. They have the right to express themselves on a question that is the same in Charlottetown, Halifax, Saint-Laurent, Sudbury or Calgary.

Unfortunately, Mr. Speaker, there is no clause providing that the government shall consult the opposition parties on the wording of the referendum question. The government has offered only three days of debate in the House on the wording of the question. This would enable the opposition parties to suggest amendments but would exclude them from the drafting process.
This bill should include a provision that the question must be approved by a majority of at least two-thirds of the House before it is put before the Canadian people. We in the Liberal Party believe that Canada needs a referendum in which Canadians will be able to determine the future of our country by answering a question that is clear and specific.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak on Bill C-81, the referendum legislation which the government has proposed. I rise with some sorrow because the government has deliberately introduced legislation that is flawed.
The government knows that there is a lot of will in this country to have a national referendum on the Constitution. I for one have a lot of concerns with regard to a national referendum because I believe that there is always the danger that minorities may be ignored when it comes to a national referendum, that they may not be fully protected.
But even with those reservations I was willing to give the government a chance. I believe there are some mechanisms that can be put in place to ensure that minorities are protected and at the same time allow for both national and regional participation by the citizens of this nation.
When I came back yesterday morning to the House and read the legislation, I was appalled with what the government has done. The government has not simply introduced legislation that enables Canadian citizens to have a referendum on the Constitution, it has deliber-

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
ately taken a number of clauses that allow it to manipulate that whole electoral process.
At the present time, Mr. Speaker, I serve on a committee that is meeting in another room in this building where we are discussing changes to the elections act. We are having those discussions after the royal commission, set up by the Prime Minister, spent $18 million listening to Canadians, studying and researching how we conduct elections in this country, how we finance elections in this country, and what limitations can be put on spending during election processes in this country.
When I look at this legislation I see that the government has taken its agenda on electoral reform. It has ignored what the Lortie royal commission has done. It has deliberately gone against the basic tenets of the royal commission.
The royal commission talked about very severe spending limits for third party advertising. This government has made that wide open. The royal commission talked about an almost all-inclusive definition of election expenses to make sure the public knows what is being spent by those who are for a candidate, those who are against a candidate, those who are for a party, those who are against a party or, in this case, those who are for a referendum question or those who are against a referendum question.
What we see here is not what the Lortie royal commission promoted. What we see here is even weaker than the present electoral law of this country. The government has not only gone in the opposite direction of Lortie. It has managed to weaken the present clauses that we have in this country.
This legislation is cynical. It speaks of a government being driven by its own agenda, its own electoral campaign, and not by any real concerns for the future of this nation.
When I rose today I said: "I rise to speak in sorrow". I mean that. This legislation could have been much better written. It could have been written so that all members of this House, with the possible exception of a few, could have been proud of that legislation. We could have all felt like participants in the wording of the question. We could have all gone out across the country and said that
the referendum was fair and why Canada was worth saving. It would not matter to us who our allies were. They could be Liberals. They could be Conservatives. We would be out there working for the future of our nation.
The previous Liberal member who spoke said that she would support any referendum legislation. I cannot give this Prime Minister a blank cheque. I cannot support this legislation as it is written. The government has spent $18 million listening to Canadians on electoral reform, on why it is necessary to have electoral fairness. This legislation goes against that very concept. The government says that it cannot limit spending or restrict the number of groups that would participate because it might received a charter challenge. That was one of the issues the Lortie royal commission looked at. It believed-and its advice was sought as well-that our Constitution allowed reasonable limits.
At this time I have proposed a number of things I do not have time to go into. We have prepared proposals for the government House leader on how they could clean up this legislation, on how we could have reasonable limits on spending and on how we could ensure federal and provincial governments do not overspend and still respect the charter. However we say there should be expenditure limits based on the voters.
We believe provincial and federal governments should be limited in the amount they can spend. We believe we can make the limits real by taking the Lortie commission recommendation and ensuring there is no co-ordination, no pooling of efforts on the referendum question, and by saying that no group can belong to more that one referendum committee.
There are ways to ensure the charter, to ensure spending by public, to allow it to spend money, but at the same time to ensure we have a fair system. We have made recommendations in a number of other areas.
I realize that my time to speak is very limited and I do have an amendment to offer this House. Before I make that amendment, I would ask the government to seriously consider what it has presented to this House and consider the fact that the Canadian public is very cynical about politicians in general, but especially about this government.
May 20, 1992

When they see this legislation, if it is not amended, and when they see large corporations spending multimillions of dollars and doing a lot of things behind the scenes that are not going to be reported, and that is what happens under this legislation, which I said is weaker than the present election laws of this country, Canadians will become more cynical about this nation. It will cost us the votes of the people who believe in a strong and united country because they cannot support the Prime Minister, they cannot support the government and they cannot support a cynical process.
I move:
That the motion be amended by deleting all the words after the
word "that" and substituting the following therefor:
This House declines to give second reading to Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada, the principles of which are objectionable in that the bill fails to:
(a)	specifically provide for limits on campaign spending by individuals, organizations and governments;
(b)	require that the results of the referendum are interpreted to ensure support and participation from all regions of Canada; and
(c)	apply rules of campaigning to the governments of Canada, the provinces and territories.

Mr. Speaker, why referendum legislation today? Why is the government tabling such a legislation before the House? First of all, we must go back a little in our history. In 1980, there was a referendum in Quebec, in which people said they agreed to a renewed Canadian federalism by ultimately saying yes to the possibility of a renewal of our country. Then, in 1982, there were discussions where, once again, Quebec found itself isolated and could not respond positively to the proposal it received at the time.
Later, in 1987, the Prime Minister succeeded in getting the agreement of the ten premiers on what is called the Meech Lake Accord, that is the five conditions put forward by Quebec so that it could say yes to the Constitution of Canada.
During the three years that followed, some premiers opposed the accord and our government, through our
Government Orders
Prime Minister, succeeded once again in getting the premiers to sign it. A few months later, the same premiers did not honour their commitment, so that the Meech Lake Accord failed and Quebec found itself isolated once again. Then, despite some difficulties at that time, our government set up some committees: the Spicer commission, and then, the Beaudoin-Edwards Committee, which was supposed to analyse the constitutional amending formula and which did an in-depth analysis of the referendum issue.
Then there was the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee, which also dealt with the referendum issue and which was somewhat saying that the government should hold at its discretion a referendum in case of a deadlock or in order to get a national consensus. But meanwhile, since the tabling of the Beaudoin-Dobbie report, there have been ongoing constitutional discussions between the first ministers or their representatives, and we might indeed end up with a deadlock during the next few weeks.
If in fact we cannot reach an agreement at the table and if we cannot obtain resolutions from each of the legislatures in order to renew our federalism, what shall we do? Shall we let the country go to pieces or shall we ultimately risk consulting the people? I think that in such a context, if there is an impasse, before Canada is divided we should go to the people. Even if the only legal way to amend the Constitution of Canada is to obtain resolutions from the different legislatures, a national referendum through which the Canadian people could express its opinion would have a tremendous impact. Given that situation, a piece of legislation on referendums seems absolutely necessary to me, even mandatory, since we must recognize that the possibility of an impasse really exists.
Mr. Speaker, what is our role as members of Parliament in such a context and how are we to analyse this bill? What are the really important values? Justice and the values of our democracy of course.
In 1898, a referendum was held in Canada on the issue of prohibition. At that time, the Quebec vote was diametrically apposed to that of the rest of Canada. In 1942, there was another referendum, a plebiscite on conscription, and again Quebecers expressed an opinion quite different from that of the other Canadians. Nonetheless, two years later, the Prime Minister decided to

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
introduce a bill to force everybody into accepting the conscription.
That is why today, for this bill, I spoke of the importance of the double majority. Why am I talking about the double majority? The Beaudoin-Edwards committee examined this question extensively and declared: "We recommend that a federal law be enacted to enable the federal government at its discretion to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal whether to confirm the existence of a national consensus or to facilitate the adoption of the required amending resolutions. The referendum should require a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions-Atlantic, Quebec, Ontario and the west".
Even if the referendum is a consultative one-and I understand my colleagues for suggesting that perhaps it might not be necessary to entrench the double majority in a bill-I maintain it would be better to mention it in a bill to make it clear that there should be a double majority, whether in the four regional divisions or in Quebec, precisely to prevent a repetition of what happened in 1942.
My second point is the question of how fair it is to limit expenses. Experts say that, under section 2 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms: "Everyone has the following fundamental freedoms: (aside from freedom of association) freedom of thought, belief, opinion and expression, including freedom of the press and other media of communication" and that these rights make it difficult to put a ceiling on expenses in the event of a referendum.
I am not a lawyer, but I had the opportunity to sit on the Beaudoin-Edwards and Beaudoin-Dobbie committees where the issue of the charter was reviewed at length. Another section of the charter states that: "The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society." In that context, I think that this particular section is as important as section 2 and that we should really seek to put a ceiling on expenses to prevent potential abuse.
As members of Parliament, there are things we can do when a bill is tabled by our government. We can try to make it better. That is why I still do not rule out the possibility of tabling amendments to our bill over the next couple of hours to ensure it is as fair as possible and in keeping with our rules of democracy. That is the context in which I intend to table, in a matter of hours, these amendments to the referendum legislation.
I have another important point to make and it is that we need a referendum act. If indeed a deadlock were reached, not having such an act could definitely be more detrimental to this country and all the values we want to uphold. We need that piece of legislation. And, in that context, I will work at improving it, using my position as a member of Parliament to make the bill better. After that, we will see.
