speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take part in this debate at second reading on Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada.
It is unfortunate that every time this government proposes something, it is on a rush-rush basis. It has been almost two years now, so the government could be much further ahead, it had ample time to introduce a bill on referendums that we, on this side, have long demanded. The government always claimed it was not necessary, it was difficult.
Now that we finally have a bill, the government is telling us that we have to pass it as quickly as possible, because otherwise it will be impossible to hold a referendum this fall. I would like, first of all, to point out to the House the fact that the Leader of the Opposition said on April 21, 1991, and I quote: "We need a process, a constitutional framework based on principles which will allow us to resolve the actual impasse quickly and equitably for Quebec and Canada as a whole." In that same speech he was proposing an approach while, as I said, the government was still dragging its feet. In order for this approach to succeed the federal government had
May 20, 1992

to hold a referendum. At that time we would have liked this referendum to be held at the beginning of 1992, in the spring, but the government now proposes fall 1992.
We support in principle the concept of a referendum but not in the way proposed by the government. Today the government wants us to pass a bill allowing for referendums, but it tells us that it might not use it. I do not understand. If we come to a constitutional agreement with the provinces, why not let the people of Canada have their say? In my opinion, the referendum should not be used only when there is no agreement, it has to be used as well when there is one, so that the question is settled once and for all.
When the Canadian Constitution was patriated in 1981-82, if we had had a referendum act, where we would have asked Canadians and Quebecers for direction on the matter, I am sure that in Quebec and in every other province the people would have voted yes and the issue would have been settled once and for all. The then premier in Quebec would have had no other choice but to accept the people's verdict, and that would have been the end of it. Whereas, we now have to go through that all over again.
What I am concerned about at this time is that even if the federal government and seven provinces representing 50 per cent of the population came to an agreement, if we do not hold a referendum, some groups in Quebec would not accept the proposals, and we would have to start all over again. Also, if we were to amend the Constitution with a referendum based on the bill before the House, some groups in Quebec would still challenge the results since this not very democratic legislation is so lacking.
So we have not solved the problem, even with a referendum to be held pursuant to this bill. It is very important for me and for my colleagues in the opposition, that the government amends this bill. I was glad to hear the previous speaker, the hon. member for Jon-quiere, say that as a member of the government, he would be proposing some amendments. I hope he will be able to convince his colleagues on his side to amend this bill right away, so we can vote for it in a democratic fashion.
Government Orders
Mr. Speaker, why do we always have to start from scratch? Yesterday, when he introduced his bill, the leader of the government in the House of Commons quoted a 1978 report which has never been approved. However, in 1981, Quebec went through such an experience, they held a referendum and passed some bills. Why not use that model? In 1980, I was involved in the referendum campaign, as the majority of politically active people in Quebec. I joined the no campaign, because I was opposed to sovereignty association. We won, but that did not stop the people on the other side of the issue from feeling betrayed, since they did not have the same opportunities. The same spending limits, the same rules applied. So, why should we fear such a form of democracy?
Since democracy is very important to the Canadian and the Quebec people, why not have a bill allowing everyone, from every political stripe and every region of the country, to feel free to speak their minds during the referendum campaign. That way, when we got the results, we would know where we stand. It is incumbent on the premiers and the Prime Minister of Canada, on the Parliament of Canada and the provincial legislatures to amend the Constitution. I do not think any politician in this country would dare ignore the will the people choose to freely express, according to democratic principles.
Unfortunately time is running out. There are just a few months left, because one way or the other, you have to bear this in mind, Mr. Speaker, if the federal government continues to lose whatever precious time we have, Quebec will decide on its own. If we do not establish some democratic rules, I fear we will not only lose the referendum, but also our country, a beautiful country everyone envies and we can stand to lose because we are stuck with this piece of legislation.
I do hope the government will agree to study the issue of double majority because it is very important. Quebecers must feel that their vote will count. If they are refused, most Quebecers will vote no, and we will start all over. But if they are accepted, it is settled. We can solve the constitutional issue and turn to economic problems.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
So it is important for the double majority to be part of this referendum bill. The whole issue of election rules is important, Mr. Speaker. It is unacceptable not to have spending limits in a democratic society. I also find it unacceptable that there are no groups. The government is not required to report and it can spend as much as it wants. I especially think that when a government represents a political party, it is dangerous for the democratic process.
As for the whole subject of election rules, Mr. Speaker, we spent $19 million on the Lortie commission. We have a referendum bill so that people can express their opinions. Although it is not an election, why does this bill not include the Lortie Commission's recommendations, after $19 million of the taxpayers' money was spent on it?
So I ask the government and government members to put pressure on the House leader, who is piloting this bill, and on the whole cabinet to present us with amendments as soon as possible or a new bill that will respect the basic principles of democracy. That means a double majority, spending limits, more equitable election rules that are in tune with our time and not an election law from 20 or 30 years ago.
You are telling me that my time is up. I hope that my colleagues on the government side, like one who got up-I hope that others will talk to their minister so that this bill is completely changed.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted that the Parliament of Canada finally has a plebiscite bill before it for debate. We have waited a year and now we have it.
My father, who was in the Canadian army during World War II, taught me an expression which they often used in the army. It was: "Hurry up and then wait". The parliamentary version of this is the other way around. Here we have to wait and then hurry up. We are now being asked to hurry up and get this legislation approved in a very short time.
It is important that we deal with this legislation in Parliament and hear argument about amendments and how it can be improved. The government House leader indicated last Friday that he would be open to debate and
amendments. As recently as today he indicated that he is planning some amendments himself and is discussing these with other parties in the House.
This bill is important because it is enabling legislation that will permit the men and women of Canada to be participants in the process of constitutional change. We have the bill and now we can work on improving it.
We should take into account that the last time Parliament debated legislation for a plebiscite was a decade or more ago, when the government of Prime Minister Trudeau felt that the same approach was necessary. Another time before that a plebiscite actually was held, that was half a century ago in 1942.
If we very briefly look at some of the things that are different this time around we can see that we are making changes in our democratic society. I will give three examples. First, compared with 1942 the franchise is broader now. It includes people as young as age 18 and it includes, because of the 1960 changes in the election law thanks to the Diefenbaker government, Canadian Indians, Inuit and Dukhobors, it includes people who had been excluded. We are going into this plebiscite with a broader franchise.
Second, unlike the plebiscite 50 years ago we are seeing disclosure of the sources of funds that are being contributed to the process. These were unheard of ideas half a century ago in Canadian electoral law.
My third example concerns the equitable distribution of broadcasting time. These again are new ideas that reflect our revolution as a democratic society. However, what more needs to be said about the 1992 plebiscite bill?
First, the title itself, referring to referendums, is a misnomer because the spokesman for the government refers to it as a plebiscite. It is a non-binding vote. Yet we have a bill that will have to be amended to change the title from referendum to plebiscite.
Last Friday I was told that this was not possible, that the government had received legal advice that you could not use such a name. Today I understand that there will be an amendment to change it. That is good. It makes me doubt a little bit more the authenticity and depth of the legal advice which the government might be relying on in this bill. If it has that problem with the title of the bill then I am more concerned about the kind and quality of the legal advice it is getting with respect to the charter
May 20, 1992

arguments, which get to the more profound dimensions of this legislation.
The fact that we have enabling legislation before the House is very important because in a mature democracy there surely must be on the statute books the enabling rules that will permit a direct vote by the people when Parliament decides it is important to allow the Canadian people to share with us the risk of decision making, and to live with the consequences of making that decision.
Seven of our provinces have such legislation. Both of the territories do. It is more than high time that we in the Parliament of Canada put permanently on our statute book this kind of enabling legislation. Which makes me think that we should amend the provision of the statute that puts a three-year sunset clause on this bill. What is the magic about 36 months? Why should this enabling legislation disappear after 36 months?
As a very minimum we should instead put in the legislation the kind of provision we find in the Lobbyist Registration Act saying that after a certain period of time a committee of Parliament will consider Parliament's experience with it and come back before Parliament with recommendations on what kind of changes might be warranted in the act.
We are a long way yet from getting the kind of legislation that I would like to see, so that we would have in the Constitution an entrenched requirement that any amendments to our Constitution would require ratification by a popular vote. That is no radical idea, certainly not for a parliamentary democracy. Our Australian cousins have been doing that since the year 1900. They have found that on 32 trips to the polls to amend their Constitution, eight times the electors have approved the amendment and the rest they have turned down.
In a parliamentary democracy if you cannot persuade a majority of the people that the amendments you want to make to the Constitution should be made then I do not think that you have a political right or a legal right, or a moral right, to change the Constitution. Ultimately in a democracy our system rests upon the consent of the governed, not their coercion but their consent. The whole elaborate superstructure-our Parliament, our courts, our police, our financial institutions, all of our organizations-has its place in our society because the Canadian people consent to this system and agree that is how it should operate.
Government Orders
We must be sure that the Canadian people are partners with us in any changes that will be made to the Constitution. It is my hope that our minister and others who are negotiating in Montreal today, and next week in Toronto and so on, can come before us all with a package of amendments that will modernize the Constitution and renew Confederation. Then we will have a chance under this legislation to go before the Canadian people and let them express their verdict on the question at the polls following a good campaign on the issue.
As for the value of having enabling legislation, I might just mention as a footnote that in 1914 Prime Minister Borden had great difficulties with the Canadian Senate. He decided in 1914 that it was time for Senate reform. He wanted to go to the people to get a mandate in a plebiscite for that kind of Senate reform. However, as he prepared for that he discovered that there was no enabling legislation in the country. By the time the Privy Council drafted it and it was ready to be brought before Parliament we were into World War I and that whole issue was off the agenda.
There have been many times in this country when our leaders-especially the veteran mature prime ministers who have been in office for some years, be they Laurier, Borden, Mackenzie King, Trudeau or Mulroney-have come to the conclusion that there is something important in the way our system functions requiring that the people be directly involved in expressing their verdict at the ballot box in a direct vote, as a plebiscite.
Therefore, we come again to write yet another line or two in this long chapter of the Canadian quest to get direct legislation that will permit a vote.
I do not agree that this is the best bill we could have. That is why I will be working with others to support the amendments that are being proposed; amendments that would see the sensible structure, as we have in the referendum bill in Quebec, of two umbrella organizations. These organizing structures do not force people to participate in a certain way but enable a fair division of broadcasting time, a fair presentation of both sides of the issue, a fair allocation of funds and a responsible limiting of expenditures in accordance with the norms that have developed over the past two or three decades in Canada to ensure that our political processes, be they elections or plebiscites, are not a rich person's game. Canadians have an intelligence that should be addressed on these

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
issues rather than simply being bombarded by the group that can spend the most money.
There are many ways in which the legislation can be improved. I am here in Parliament with my colleagues to work for those amendments and to see that this legislation is improved. I am certainly glad to be supporting it because this is a day that many of us have waited a long time to see.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to stand in the House today to address the federal referendum legislation.
At the outset I would like to say that there are a couple of principles that are particularly important whenever one considers legislation of this type, particularly one that is so important to the future of Canada and all Canadians.
We must check the principles against this particular legislation in order to ensure that it addresses the legitimate needs of this country and its people.
I think most colleagues would agree that the Constitution belongs to the people, not to the politicians and not to the bureaucrats. Canadians should have the final say on any constitutional reform package. On that measure the proposed legislation falls short.
As well, I believe that our national referendum should allow Canadians to say yes to each other. All Canadians should have the same opportunity, the same chance to express their views on the same question or questions, not only some Canadians and not only some Canadians in a series of provincial referendum questions.
I want to remind my colleagues, as well as listeners, that it was the Liberal Party of Canada under the leadership of the hon. member for Beausejour who first proposed a national referendum to get us out of this constitutional impasse a little more than a year ago. It was part of his nine point plan to bring about some sort of constitutional resolution in our country.
Canadians are disappointed that it has taken the government some time to get its act together. They recall that this kind of legislation had been promised in the throne speech of May 1991 and the government backed away from that promise shortly thereafter. It was promised again in November and the government backed away again. Finally it has come forward. That is a good sign and I hope that it is something that works out well for all of us.
I was surprised right from the beginning as a member of two constitutional committees, the Beaudoin-Ed-wards constitutional committee and the Beaudoin-Dob-bie constitutional committee, that the NDP has not been supportive of a national referendum. At most it has given lukewarm support, if any at all. I am surprised at that particular position because it seems to me that the legislation has a lot of merit which the NDP has not considered as deeply as it might have.
I want to commend the government for finally having come forward with referendum legislation to permit Canadians to say yes to each other.
However, I still have many concerns and here are some of them. The referendum is still only optional. That breeds uncertainty and causes some considerable anxiety: will it happen, will it not, when, where, et cetera?
It has no spending limits. I recognize there are certain difficulties with spending limits, but at the same time and with all due respect some limits could have been established among fair players.
I am surprised that it would appear we are looking at a majority of Canadians and not a second majority, a majority of the four or five large regions of Canada would have to say yes.
I would have liked to have seen as well a commitment from the Prime Minister and his government to withdraw any constitutional agreement if it did not receive support from the majority of all regions of Canada, quite apart from the over-all majority.
Perhaps my greatest concern is with respect to the question, deciding upon the question. Clearly there has to be consultation. Clearly the government has to approach this with an openness of spirit and a commitment to consult and to come forward with the best
May 20, 1992

Government Orders
question or questions that will get the support of all parties.
If it were not to do that I fear it would get into serious difficulties, and we know what the potential price is if that were to occur.

What also bothers me, is that there are quite a few questions for which there are still no answers. I mentioned this earlier, but it bears repeating because I think this is very important. Will there be a referendum, yes or no? If so, where? Across the country, in certain provinces or regions? We do not know the answer. And of course, when? We do not have the answer to that either. I think all this tends to create a feeling of uncertainty that is not well received by most Canadians.

Will all Canadians throughout this great land be able to vote on the referendum?

We do not know that either.

Will it be a vote on the same questions? Or, will the provincial and territorial questions, if there are some, somehow be able to replace those that would be posed in a national referendum? What is the question? What are the questions?

Yes, what is the question and what will the questions be? To me, that is the crux of this debate.

Another element which is closely related and equally important is: How will it be drawn up? Will the government simply come forward and say: "Here it is"? Or, will the government consult with the various parties in the House and with other Canadians in order to ensure that it is as sensitive, as comprehensive and as meaningful as it might be?
I will take this opportunity to make certain suggestions. If somehow after this exercise, assuming there is a referendum for the whole of the country, we have not addressed the aboriginal question of self-government, we are in serious difficulty.

If we have not addressed the distinct society Quebec wants, we are in serious trouble.

We cannot avoid the question of the veto. That question must be addressed and there are a number of proposed solutions. One is clearly found in the Beau-doin-Edwards constitutional committee report where there is a proposed approach to having a majority in regions and it is defined therein.
We must also sort out either on the referendum question or elsewhere the whole question of division of powers. We cannot continue to have the dysfunctionality that we now have and the difficulties that it causes. Very often it is unclear what level of government delivers what services for its people.

So the division of powers is one of the essential issues. [English]
I would also suggest we need to address in a very sensitive way one group that often feels left out of any constitutional discussions and debate on perhaps the Canada clause. It is those Canadians who have come from other lands, those Canadians who are of ancestry other than aboriginal, English or French. There is a wonderful opportunity, if it is done correctly and with sensitivity, to ensure they feel they are a full, significant and meaningful partner in this country.
In concluding, I have a few short comments to make. We have a unique opportunity to try and settle the constitutional question once and for all, to find a solution that will not please all Canadians but the majority of Canadians, so that we can get on with the major challenges facing our country today: the economic situation, unemployment, poverty, the fact that so many people have to go to food banks. It seems to me this is a golden opportunity to try and settle the matter and start doing something about the recession in this country.

It is a great opportunity for Canada and for Canadians. If this proposed referendum is used sensitively, I think it can finally bring constitutional peace to our great nation. If used improperly, however, it could be the end of our great country. It could create a lot of divisions. I am not just talking about the division between the rest of

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
Canada and Quebec, I am talking divisions within the whole of the country.
Therefore, I urge the government to listen and listen very carefully to the people of Canada, to listen to the various political parties to see what it is that they have to offer, to make sure that this particular initiative is one that bears very positive fruit. I urge the government as well to co-operate with all parties. This is a time to rise above partisanship. This is a time to do what is right for Canada and for all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, as I begin I would like to repeat what my colleagues have already stated. This legislation is a precautionary measure. No decision to hold a referendum has been made. At the present time there is no federal legislation to permit a referendum. This legislation would make a referendum possible.
In February 1992 the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee report stated: "We recommend that a federal law be enacted to enable the federal government at its discretion to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal".
Canadians from across our country spoke to the committee and recommended that a referendum be considered. Many Canadians are pleased that the government is listening to Canadians and following the advice of the committee, the advice that was endorsed by all major parties.
Legislation must be in place to allow a referendum before the Chief Electoral Officer can begin to make preparations to hold a referendum. It is estimated that three months are needed for such preparations. That is to say, if this legislation were to be passed by mid-June, then the Chief Electoral Officer would be able to have everything ready for a referendum no sooner than mid-September.
The government is simply looking ahead, seeing that there may be a decision to hold a federal referendum and saying if this decision is the one taken, then let us be ready.
I would also like at this time to reassure all Canadians that this legislation would only apply to a referendum called by the federal government and would not in any
way affect the right of provinces to hold their own referenda if they choose to do so.
Canadians know that the referendum our government is considering is a referendum on constitutional reform. As the Beaudoin-Dobbie report noted, one of the most positive results of the patriation process is the degree of interest expressed by the people of Canada in their Constitution.
Since 1982 the people of Canada have insisted on being involved in all aspects of constitutional change. I believe this characteristic of Canadians is one of our strengths as a nation.
There are many forms that public involvement can take and a federal referendum should not, at this stage, be ruled out.
As a member of Parliament from western Canada, it is appropriate that I remind my colleagues from central Canada that Canadians living in the west have felt excluded from decision-making in the past. The huge population concentrated in the centre of our country seems not to always hear the suggestions or concerns from the west. Whenever anyone feels that his thoughts and ideas are not being heard it is frustrating. The more significant the issue, the more irritation is felt at being ignored or overlooked.
Historically there have been 44 advisory referenda or plebiscites held in Canadian provinces. Of these 44, 31 have been held in the four western provinces. So it is not surprising that many westerners believe that a referendum might be helpful. It is important to western Canadians and I believe to all Canadians that suggestions from all regions of our country be considered.
This government is doing that. This legislation says clearly we are seriously considering a referendum. If we decide that a referendum is the appropriate tool to use we will be ready and able to use it.
There are five possible ways to amend the Constitution of Canada. These five possibilities have been in place since the patriation of the Constitution in 1982. The general procedure in section 38 of the Constitution Act requires the consent of Parliament and seven of the provinces with 50 per cent of the population. This section of the amending formula is the one that the government is planning to use during this cycle of constitutional reform.
May 20, 1992

Some Canadians are wondering why the government can use this less stringent section of the amending formula when it was necessary to have all 10 provinces verify the Meech Lake Accord. The answer is that the Meech Lake Accord contained an amendment to the amending formula itself so it needed unanimity to be accepted.
The current proposal is not expected to include any amendments to the amending formula. Therefore, the current proposal is expected to need the approval of Parliament and the approval of seven provinces with 50 per cent of the population.
Some people wonder if there are safeguards to assure that the referendum is fair. This bill does not change any safeguards for fairness that are already established under Canadian law. The Canada Elections Act would provide the basic framework for the referendum and this includes practical aspects such as the qualifications of voters, et cetera.
The wording of the question posed in a referendum must be voted on and approved by both the House and the Senate. So there is no possibility, nor is there any wish on the government side, that this be a secretive process. If the government does decide to hold a referendum, a referendum proclamation must be issued within 45 days following the approval of the question that is to be put to the Canadian people.
Any federal referendum call today must be consistent with the Canadian charter of rights and fundamental freedoms. The advice we have suggests that limits on spending on umbrella committees, for the yes or the no sides, are not expected to meet the requirements of the charter and therefore are not included in the legislation.
In order for everyone to be aware of the major participants in a referendum campaign, groups which intend to participate in the referendum in a major way-that is anyone who intends to spend more than $5,000-must register and disclose all expenses and contributions, including the names of the contributors of over $250.
Some people have asked why the government is not required to register in the same way other campaign participants are if it spends on this campaign. The registration requirements in the bill are intended to
Government Orders
make sure the public knows who is spending significant amounts of money to present their views. Government spending is already visible and governments are accountable to the public for all their spending.
There are other safeguards to ensure fairness. It is necessary that the referendum campaign be at least 36 days long and that gives everyone an opportunity to present his views. Free broadcasting time will be allocated equally to both sides of the question. There is no provision in the legislation for public funds to be given to those campaigning. There will be equal opportunity for all sides of the issue to purchase additional time in the media. It is also worth noting that there is a sunset clause included. That simply means in three years this legislation will cease to exist.
In closing, I would like to emphasize that the purpose of the legislation is to be ready to hold a referendum if the government wishes to do so. The government is listening to the Canadian people and wants them to continue their involvement in the constitutional process. There is strong regional support for a referendum on proposed constitutional change. The government is responding to this recommendation and is seriously considering the possibility. Finally, a federal referendum would be a fair referendum.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity this afternoon to make a few comments on Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada.
The first comment I would like to make concerns the title of the bill itself. It is my understanding from repeated comments by the Prime Minister and other members of the government that we are not going to have a referendum, if there is a vote at all. They keep talking about a plebiscite and it certainly piques my curiosity when we have a bill come before the House that refers to a referendum. I am not aware it even refers to the word "plebiscite" any place in the bill.
I am pleased the government has finally brought forward and introduced legislation. I can only say it is a start. I am certain the constituents in my riding of Prince Edward-Hastings are pleased because we in Prince Edward-Hastings, and we in the Liberal Party, have been calling on the government now for well over a year to come forward with some sort of enabling legislation.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
At the present time Canadians are seeking direction. However, when we look at the legislation, it is noticeable that the government continues to act as though it thinks there is only one voice that Canadians need to hear and that is the government's voice. It thinks it is the voice of an infallible ruler.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order, please. There is a debate going on in this part of this House. I would appreciate it if the gentlemen who wish to talk or discuss something would go behind the curtain.

Mr. Speaker, I began to wonder on which side of the House the debate was going on but I did check and my microphone was on and theirs was not.
I repeat that the government seems to think that it has the complete and only right to speak on behalf of Canadians on this issue. We know the folly of this notion because this is the same government that is jamming legislation down the throats of Canadians and has been for a number of years now. It is the same government that continues to lose its credibility with the Canadian public.
I do praise the government for bringing forward the legislation, but I fault the government for the quality of it. The government has unashamedly pronounced on the form of this legislation, reserving for itself the authority to determine the question, and that at a later date without any consultation. This, in spite of assurances over the past number of months from the highest ranks of the government benches, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and the Prime Minister, that opposition parties and the Canadian public would have input in the legislation.
I remind Canadians again, that did not happen. The bill was presented to the opposition parties. There was not any discussion whatsoever and it was presented as we see it here today.
The government has not only failed to consult on enabling legislation to conduct a plebiscite or referendum which I repeat should have happened, was promised to happen but it does not seem to realize that this is an issue of our nation's destiny. We must make it very clear to the Canadian public and to Parliament there may not be a vote at all, so let us not be naive enough to think that just because the legislation is there it is going to be used.
The reasons for that simply evade me. Why? I recognize as well as anyone the potential for divisiveness that a national referendum would hold but such a risk must be taken when the contrast to not doing it is the risk of not holding a vote at all.
My colleague from Cape Breton-East Richmond put it appropriately in the House yesterday. He said that Canadians:
-are an intelligent and educated people and they usually demonstrate a remarkable sophistication in their political behaviour. The Canadian population of 1992 is as well prepared as a whole as any group of officials, elected or not, to make the decision on the basic structure of its government. It is unreasonable and unconscionable to suggest otherwise.
So I state again that the government has an obligation to conduct a vote.
This description definitely applies to the constituents in Prince Edward-Hastings riding who have regularly challenged me on every facet of the constitutional debate with insights that quite honestly continue to educate me well beyond the understanding of these issues that comes from many of the presentations and speeches I have heard in the House.
There are reasons why a referendum or a plebiscite must be held on this government's final constitutional package. A national vote would go a very long way toward addressing the public's cynicism, a cynicism which arose after the collapse of the Meech Lake proposals in the wake of the political engineering and the closed door negotiations that took place at that time.
Second, the final say in the matter rightfully belongs to the Canadian public. Third, a referendum will finally allow us as a country to put this matter to bed once and for all.
I do not believe that a referendum should be an option. It should be an obligation and it should be mandatory for the government to conduct one. In fact, a referendum should be mandatory before any future government proceeds to revise the Constitution of this country. The people must not be excluded from the process of changing the way they are governed.
The Constitution was created for people, not for politicians and bureaucrats, and being their property it is also their sole right to permit such changes. If a referendum is going to be held, it should go well beyond what Bill C-81 is proposing at the present time. As has been stated even by government members in the House here today, it needs to be fixed, it needs to be improved. The vote must be held nation-wide, giving every citizen in all regions of the country an opportunity to express

their opinion on the same question or questions. I repeat, every citizen in all regions.
The results in order to carry any weight in the government's consideration of whether or not to proceed must reflect the clear majority of the will of the nation and the will of the nation as a whole, as well as the feeling and the will of each region. This will provide a clear demonstration of our collective will to remain united as a country, while at the same time preventing any misinterpretation, claiming the imposition of a constitutional arrangement by any portion of the nation on another portion of the nation.
Further on the issue of conducting a fair vote, this legislation must be amended to make the process transparent and equitable for all sides of the issue. I am glad to learn that there is some indication by the Elouse leader today in an announcement that there will be some changes introduced and amendments introduced that will provide some spending limits on the registered committees.
We must ensure that the losing side will not be allowed to claim the vote was bought by the rich and the powerful. This means that both sides must somehow be limited in their over-all expenditures.
The government House leader said last week in the House and again this week in the House that he is open to amendments and changes to improve the bill. I hope we can take him and the government at their word. It needs some improvement. It needs to be changed. We must take the present Bill C-81 and fix it and make it better.
This is the challenge before us as a Parliament, it is the challenge before us as a country. I know that if the will and the desire is there, we can rise and meet that challenge.

Mr. Speaker, I am rising to speak at second reading of Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada. It is very easy to support in principle the idea of a constitutional referendum. As my colleagues who have spoken before me have indicated, the principle
Government Orders
of a referendum on constitutional matters is one that we support.
Now our challenge as parliamentarians is to look at the specifics. The specifics are very important in terms of defining what it is that we are setting out to do.
We all support the principle of hockey, if I might use it as an example. The rules in hockey have always been carefully outlined and understood by all the participants because the rules have been defined and upheld by a group with responsibilities, a group which for the most part has the respect of all the participants in that hockey game. Of course, I speak of the referees and the league itself which have set the rules.
Not your favourite team, Mr. Speaker, the Edmonton Oilers, not the Toronto Maple Leafs and certainly not the Vancouver Canucks or the Montreal Canadiens would step on the ice in a Stanley Cup final game without a referee. They certainly would not step on the ice without a set of rules. Not all of their skill, their determination, their energy or their emotion would help any of those teams succeed in their chosen goal and victory without division or discord if those rules were not understood, agreed upon and enforced with the co-operation of all of the players.
We are not playing hockey and the future of Canada is not a game. But as a country in crisis we are skating on very thin ice. We want to play the game. We want to enjoy the game. We want to enjoy our country with all its diversity, its history, its people and, more important, we want to enjoy its future, but discord and division is threatening our enjoyment of that future.
A national referendum in these exceptional circumstances is one way to ensure public participation in the decision-making process that will once again help us to enjoy our country, to enjoy the game and put the referee back on the ice in the most important game of the year.
When I speak to my constituents, the support for a referendum is almost universal. In fact, for most of my constituents the outline of how it is put together and run is somewhat secondary. For the most part they take it for granted that when a referendum is called, the rules will be in place and all you need is a question and they will help to provide the answer.

Mr. Speaker, you know from your own election experience that it is not that easy. Our task as parliamentarians is to provide the rules and make those rules acceptable not only here in the House of Commons, but to people right across Canada. Unless those rules are accepted by all the participants before the game begins, the results of that game may be held in suspect.
My colleagues from Yorkton-Melville and Churchill who spoke earlier outlined some of the matters of concern that they have and I share about this referendum bill. Those concerns are so great that they throw doubt on our ability to accept the principles laid down by this legislation. Therefore, we suspect that Canadians would not be well served if these are the only rules they have to play by. Those concerns, as outlined, include the fact that there are no spending limits, that cabinet alone can trigger the timing of the referendum; that the question to be asked will eventually be decided by government despite the discussion about parliamentary vote; there is no awaiting the results to ensure that the regions feel included in this whole process. That latter concern is my main concern at this moment.
The current constitutional debate in western Canada focuses primarily on the reform of the Senate. Why? Canadians feel left out of the process and, in fact, feel left out of the country because the decisions made in the populated centres of Canada, the provinces of Ontario and Quebec, are often made at the expense of the rest of the country because of that large population base in the centre of Canada.
Western Canadians feel let down by the House of Commons which is accountable to the population centres of the country. Therefore, they want a Senate that is more accountable to the regions and that serves as the hub of most of the argument we hear, not only in the coffee shops but in the forums and reviews brought before the Spicer commission and others.
Now we have a referendum bill which does exactly what western Canadians fear most. That is, leave in the hands of the voters of central Canada the powers of decision-making within constitutional reform. We have to get out of this way of thinking. We have to write the rules that will ensure that western Canadians are not again ignored in this process. There must be a way to
ensure that the interpretation of the results of this non-binding referendum ensures that the government weighs the views of western Canadians well.
My colleague, the member for Yorkton-Melville, said yesterday in this House and I quote: "I think that it should not be possible to change the Constitution of Canada without the massive support of Canadians. If there were a national referendum on the federal government's major proposals like those in the report that the parliamentary committee published two months ago, and western Canadians were opposed, I think it should be out of the question to change our Constitution without western Canada's support".
I could not have said it better. The member for Yorkton-Melville outlined what I hear on the streets of my constituency daily in that very brief comment.
In an article in The Ottawa Citizen published May 17, the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore, a referendum expert and a member of the government party said, and I quote: "If we call ourselves a democracy, we must not be afraid to use democratic procedures". Well, we are in the process of defining one of those democratic procedures and we are in the process of establishing the rules that will guide that democratic procedure.
In the spirit of co-operation which comes from my personal desire to rebuild a fragile Canadian Constitution, I urge the government to put its partisan desires aside and create a more acceptable, fair and equitable procedure to ensure that we have a strong referendum should it become necessary to do so. The Constitution, as has been said, does belong to the people of Canada, not the politicians. Therefore, is it asking too much that we create a referendum process that will over time help to rebuild this country and this nation? Is it too much to ask that Canadians are able to truly participate in the democratic decision-making process in this unique and unusual and most exceptional period of time, at a time when Canadians are more cynical about government than at any other time in our history? Is it too much to ask that government take the time to build an all-inclusive process that will help to rebuild respect for participatory democracy inside a united Canada? Mr. Speaker, I do not believe that is too much to ask. In fact, I consider it a very minimum.

Mr. Speaker, the bill now before us could be an important factor in resolving some vital decisions at this stage in the political history of our nation. That is one reason why I am particularly gratified to have an opportunity to participate in this debate.
Like many other members here, I am sure, I have heard from a number of my constituents who expressed interest in the idea that they and all other Canadians could have some direct influence upon the decisions that are to be made about our Constitution. In fact, I have received some petitions signed by several hundred residents of Durham constituency. The wording of these petitions should be noted. They request a referendum in which the Canadian people could vote to accept or to reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government, with the result to be binding on Parliament.
While one can understand the reasoning behind that wording and even sympathize with it, the circumstances we are dealing with here do not permit such a final and binding public decision. I believe it would be useful and helpful to spend a few moments explaining why.
To begin with, I would suggest that it would be immensely helpful if all of us involved in this debate would use precise language when describing the type of vote that is proposed. In saying that, I must add an important qualifier; that I am only referring to those of us who speak in English. My capability in the other official language is such that I would not attempt to comment on the fine nuances. However, in the English language there are two words that do describe the type of popular vote proposed here. One is referendum, the other is plebiscite.
There is a difference in the meaning of these two words, a distinction that may seem subtle but that is also very important. Throughout much of the discussion the two words "referendum" and "plebiscite" have been used as though they were interchangeable and synonymous, which they are not. I fear that this could well be confusing and even misleading.
The Shorter Oxford English Dictionary defines plebiscite as, and I quote: "In modem politics a direct vote of the whole of the electors of a state to decide a question of public importance; also, by extension, a public expression
Government Orders
with or without binding force of the wishes or opinion of a community". The same Oxford Dictionary gives this definition for referendum: "The act, practice or principle-of submitting the direct decision of a question at issue to the whole body of voters". In fact, a plebiscite is an expression of opinion by the people, with or without binding force; while in a referendum the voters are asked to make a direct and final decision.
It is extremely important for all Canadians to know and understand, if such a vote should prove necessary, that what they are being asked for is an expression of their opinion in a plebiscite. I understand that the government will bring forward an amendment to clarify the title and the language around this bill. Whether it is binding or not, that expression of opinion obviously would be a very significant consultative procedure. Elected politicians in our form of parliamentary democracy could only ignore the outcome at their own peril.
However, the vote in that plebiscite cannot decide the matter finally. For constitutional reasons it cannot be binding upon this Parliament or upon the legislatures of various provinces. There is a very simple reason for that, something that we do not have the power to change unilaterally. The formula for making constitutional amendments is enshrined in the Constitution itself. That formula, adopted by the federal government and the provinces in 1982, requires that any amendments to the Constitution must have the approval of at least seven provinces representing no less than 50 per cent of Canada's total population.
There is nothing this government or this Parliament can do to alter that without the agreement of the provinces. That obviously would be virtually impossible amidst the current ongoing constitutional negotiations. This Parliament has no power to tell the provinces what they must do on constitutional amendments.
These are very important considerations. While I have dwelt on them at some length, I believe it is essential that all Canadians have a clear understanding of exactly what we are doing with this legislation and why. There is some consensus that public dissatisfaction over the outcome of the Meech Lake negotiations was due as much to the process followed as to the actual content of the agreement. People felt that crucial decisions were being made about their future and that they were closed out of the discussions.

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
To be fair to all politicians involved in the Meech Lake discussions, the process was not their fault. They had to use the only procedure that was then available to them. However, today and in the future Canada's people must also have a part in that process.
I recognize that there could well be a requirement for a constitutional plebiscite within the coming months. However I also believe that this form of public consultation, be it through a plebiscite or a referendum, should only be used on rare occasions when needed to settle the most contentious issues.
One reason that I suggest such restriction is the tremendous expense involved. It is estimated that the cost of holding any plebiscite would exceed $100 million, and this is at a time when all of us are deeply concerned about government expenditures and reducing the deficit and national debt.
Any such vote on any contentious and emotional issue carries the risk of being veiy divisive and it could accentuate the existing divisions within our country. I am told by those who voted in the 1942 conscription plebiscite that is exactly what happened then; communities, provinces, religious and language groups became pitted against each other. To this day in my area there are families who still bear the emotional scars of that conscription plebiscite.
All of us have heard about the family members in Quebec who took opposing sides in the 1980 sovereignty referendum and who still, 12 years later, have not been able to reconcile or heal those fractures.
We must do all we can to ensure that Canadians understand that this legislation is a necessary precautionary measure, that it will permit the federal government to consult all Canadians if that will bring the current round of constitutional negotiations to a successful conclusion.

Mr. Speaker, the House of Commons is currently examining Bill C-81, legislation that will enable the federal government to hold a national referendum on the Canadian Constitution.
The Canadian experience in that field has not been successful. The current Constitution does not provide for a binding referendum. Consequently, our referendum will only be consultative.

Mr. Speaker, since Confederation, Canada used the consultative referendum approach twice: the first time in 1898 on the prohibition issue, and the second time in 1942 on the conscription issue. That last experience left a bitter feeling among a lot of Canadians. On the other hand, in the current political context, where people want to take a more active part in the debate, instead of leaving the decision to the elected representatives, the referendum approach deserves serious consideration.
Mr. Speaker, it is a change of policy for me who used to oppose referendums, but since this government has destroyed or has almost finished destroying the people's trust in politicians, I think that, today, we must let the people decide on such important issues as the future of our country.
In so doing, we will have to pursue the objective of a new Constitution that will preserve the linguistic duality, the regional interests and the national unity. That is why
May 20,1992

on April 21, 1991, the Liberal leader was the first to suggest the idea of a national referendum by proposing a nine-point action plan, including a national referendum with a double majority.
For the Liberal caucus, it is clear that all Canadians must be consulted and, consequently, be able to express themselves on the same issues in all parts of the country. It is clear that in addition to a national majority, the constitutional amendment proposal must be approved by every region of the country. The Atlantic provinces, Quebec, Ontario, the western provinces and the territories would thus have a veto. In that way, the double majority protects regional interests against an imposed national will.
If one of the regions decided to reject the proposal, the federal government should not follow through with its constitutional amendment project as presented.
Liberals regret that the Conservative government did not include this double majority provision in the bill before the House. Also, in order to keep this referendum from being divisive, the government must ensure that it has an appropriate set of rules since, as was noted by the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing, and I quote: "Such a mechanism can easily fall into the hands of wealthy interest groups."
That is why the Liberal caucus believes it is important to limit spending by both the yes and the no sides. We believe that a referendum must take place in all fairness. We favour umbrella committees and a reasonable spending limit by each side of the issue.
Canadians do not want the result to be bought; they want it to be well deserved. Unfortunately, the Conservative government's Bill C-81 contains no spending ceiling.
Announced a year ago in the Speech from the Throne on May 13, 1991, the legislation on a national referendum was presented to the House a year later. The referendum process is off to a bad start. Let us be honest: the Conservative government had promised to consult the opposition parties. It did not consult us. It informed the House leaders of its plan-that is all.
I suspect that the government's intention with this bill is to set up a mechanism for calling a snap federal election. At least that is what clause 38 of the bill leads
Government Orders
us to believe. It says that no enumeration shall be required if an election is called within a year of the referendum date. Furthermore, no clause in the bill says that the government must consult the opposition parties on the wording of the referendum question.
The government has proposed only three days of parliamentary debate on the wording of the question, thus restricting, in my view, the right of members of this House to speak on the question. Nevertheless, it is important for members to ensure that their constituents are perfectly aware of what they will be asked to vote on. The government's failure to consult here is a bad omen for what this referendum campaign has in store for us.
We Liberals, Mr. Speaker, think that any constitutional change at this time should be approved by all Canadians and all regions of this country, not only one province, but all regions. Canada's future depends on the choice that we will have to make. We think that the final decision must belong to the people directly.

While I may support holding a referendum in principle there are a number of aspects of this bill which concern me. One of these aspects is the absence of spending limits on referendum expenditures. There are no spending limits in Bill C-81. The only provisions are that groups spending more than $5,000 on a referendum campaign must be registered and contributions over $250 must be declared.
Without a ceiling on spending by various groups during a referendum campaign the process will be flawed because the amount of money a group has to spend will become more important than the free democratic expression of Canadians.
Canadians do not want a result that has been bought. They want a result that is fair and deserved. The question of spending limits is a question of fairness, not of freedom.
We have only to look at the example of the last election to show us the dangers inherent in the absence of spending limits. The report of the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing notes: "Third parties, including individuals, corporations, labour unions and other groups spent more than $4.7 million on advertising for the 1988 campaign-most of the money

May 20, 1992
Government Orders
was spent on the issue of free trade-four times as much money was spent to promote free trade as to oppose it".
We do not want to repeat the experience of the 1988 election, particularly when the unity of our country, Canada, is at sake. The referendum campaign must not become a free-for-all with those with the biggest wallets dominating the debate. The government may argue that spending limits contravene the right of freedom of expression as guaranteed by section 2 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
We can look at the Alberta court decision in 1984, brought on by the challenge from the National Citizens' Coalition. This decision found that the relevant section of the Canada Elections Act on spending limits on a third party was an unjustified restriction on freedom of expression.
The federal government decided not to act on this decision by the Alberta court. Furthermore, Elections Canada decided not to enforce the law, even though the court decision was not binding outside of Alberta. The result of these decisions, as the report of the electoral reform notes, was to destroy:
-the overall effectiveness of the legislative framework for promoting fairness in the exercise of freedom of expression and of democratic rights during Canadian elections-Without fairness, we may continue to have a "free" society, but we would certainly diminish the "democratic character of our society".
However, the charter does provide for reasonable limits on the freedoms guaranteed by the charter.
In the exceptional case of a referendum, it seems to me we should carefully examine the danger of uncontrolled spending by various groups versus a reasonable limit on freedom of expression.
If the government hesitates to go to court on this matter, why not refer-and the government can do it-this matter to the Supreme Court of Canada for a decision on whether spending limits contravene the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. If the government was concerned about democracy it could have done so. It had the time to do so in the last year, it could have done so earlier.
In conclusion, I want to quote from an opinion by Professor E. P. Mendes, Faculty of Law, University of Western Ontario.
I would suggest the appropriate standard is that laid down by Justice Sopinka in the R. v. Butler decision that Parliament is entitled to have a "reasonable apprehension of harm" resulting from the dangers which the legislation is attempting to avoid. It would be quite easy for the government to have proved in an appeal from Justice Medhurst's decision that there is a reasonable apprehension of harm resulting from unlimited spending during elections or referendums.
Perhaps the reasons why the government did not appeal Justice Medhurst's decision and why they do not wish to put spending limits in any referendum legislation have nothing to do with Charter of Rights and Freedoms or with law at all.
I claim that Professor Mendes' decision is something of which we should take note.

Before I say anything on the bill, I would like to praise the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore, a truly democratic Conservative, for a long time a voice in the wilderness, someone who has been promoting referendums, plebiscites, and more direct democracy. I think a lot of praise is due my colleague.
I would also like to thank the federal government and the Prime Minister, for considering the referendum, the plebiscite legislation. It is a big step for the government to be considering this kind of a method of solving some of our nation's problems.
I would like particularly to take this opportunity to say thank you as well on behalf of my constituents to the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs. He is trying to do his best for Canada. He is in his 20th year in federal politics. Twenty years is a long time to serve your country. There have not been all that many wins. There have been a lot of difficulties and failures along the way for anyone in public life that long. I would just like to pass along my thanks to him.
He is doing something for Canada, and most of the people in this Chamber are doing something for Canada too. The people who are here right now to debate this bill are doing something for Canada. The people here care enough to make sure the right legislation is going to be in place to ensure the future of our country.
A few moments ago those watching this debate could not hear but there are a few people in this Chamber who are taking exception to some of the remarks I am

making. They are members of a political party that has been an obstruction to this country.
It is tough to sit in this Chamber sometimes and look across and see a few members who do not share a vision of Canada but who view this nation as being broken, battered, bloodied and knocked down in the world stage, from being a modern country that most people in the world die to live in to some Third World country which would have an economy just a fraction of the size that it is today.
Maybe that is a good thing. Maybe it is a good thing there are separatists in this Chamber now. Maybe that will help wake up a few people. Maybe the whole referendum and plebiscite situation will in the end be good. It may take people and shake them by the shoulders and say to them that your country is at risk. Your country is at risk because there are people who sit in the federal House of Commons, in Parliament, who want the destruction of this country. In terms of referendum or plebiscite or whatever we are going to call it I would just like to say, based on the feedback from my constituents of Halton-Peel, that this is something they very much want. It is very much the kind of thing they have been asking for, that is a direct mechanism to become involved in what has turned into an all too long constitutional debate.
As with everything else there are good things and bad things about direct democracy. There are risks and rewards, plebiscites and referenda. I think back to the Meech Lake accord experience. The polls showed us after Meech Lake failed that roughly 70 per cent of Canadians did not agree with Meech. However, the same poll showed us that about 73 per cent of Canadians did not know what was in the Meech Lake package. Had there been a referendum, direct democracy, a plebiscite on the failure of the Meech Lake accord or the success of it, it would have failed. Circumstances led to that failing anyway.
There were other influences at play during the time the Meech Lake accord was being discussed. A lot of my constituents were probably turned off the whole package by Quebec's language laws and changes to those laws which were brought in around the same time and which a lot of people confused with what was in the Meech Lake accord.

It is ironic now that my constituents may see the day coming before long when they are asked to vote in a plebiscite on something that essentially may ratify what was in the Meech Lake accord that most people did not understand and rejected.

Maybe it is the right time after the Spicer commission, after the Beau-doin-Edwards report on constitutional change, after the Dobbie-Beaudoin report on the specifics of how our country may be renewed, after all those constitutional conferences that hopscotched across the country ever week, after the "ordinary Canadians" were involved in this whole process and after all the weekly meetings of bureaucrats and the meeting now in Montreal. Mr. Speaker, this evening I want to speak in favour of the concept of Bill C-81, the referendum legislation.
We in the Official Opposition agree with the idea of a referendum. In fact we have been calling for a referendum for over a year. When our leader presented his nine point plan back in April of 1991, a referendum was one of the main points.
We believe that the Constitution belongs to the people, not to the politicians, not to the government, not to the bureaucrats, but to the people.
The Constitution differs from other laws because it is the basic law of the land. It is the Constitution which gives the Parliament of Canada authority, as well as the federal government and provincial governments. We believe that all Canadians should be consulted and that
May 20,1992

they should have a final say in this constitutional reform package.
This government has been flip-flopping for more than a year on the question of a constitutional referendum. In the throne speech of May 1991 it promised referendum legislation. In the early fall of that year it backed away from the promise and then by November the referendum was back on again. Then it was off again.
Now we have legislation before us, Bill C-81. However, this legislation does not say that a referendum will be held, it says that a referendum may be held. In other words, it does not require the government to hold one. I believe that is the fundamental flaw in this legislation.
A referendum is the only way to give real legitimacy to the constitutional reform package. The people of Canada will no longer accept backroom deals. We had the Meech Lake round, and as we heard the Prime Minister admit and say, he rolled the dice. Canadians want a chance to say yes to each other and yes to Canada.
A second flaw in this bill, and I believe it is a major flaw, is that it ignores the principle of regional majorities. I believe there must be a double majority. In other words, there must be a majority of Canadians who vote for the constitutional reform package, but on top of that there must be a majority in the different regions of Canada.
This bill does not require that. It does not require that there be a majority in each region. It does not require that each region must agree with or support the constitutional proposal. I think that regional majorities are important. If we had a referendum and a region of Canada, such as the western part of Canada, voted against the constitutional package then I do not think we should proceed.
I believe that there should be a double majority, that across Canada the majority of Canadians agree but there also should be a majority in each region. Otherwise, for the government to push ahead would cause disunity and division within the country.
A third weakness in this legislation that we have before us is in the process of writing the question that Canadians would be asked. It is very important what the question is, how it is worded and how it is put.
Government Orders
In the past in Canada the three political parties have worked together on many matters of great national importance, This certainly happened during the 1981-82 constitutional process as well as during the 1987-88 constitutional process. There is no reason why all three parties should not be actively involved in writing the referendum question.
Yet this is a government that has failed to consult the opposition on the legislation we have before us today. It promised that it would consult the opposition. It promised that its members would consult us. Yet all the government did was inform us as to what would be in this legislation.
Furthermore, this legislation does not provide for any consultation on the question that would be in the referendum with opposition parties.
I think that is wrong. The other parties should be consulted. The question should not be worked out exclusively by the government. The government proposes only three days of debate on this very crucial referendum question. Three days. Unless the debate is extended it would mean that only 25 per cent of the members in this House of Commons would be able to speak on this question.
On top of that, the opposition members would not be allowed to propose any substantial changes. They could make only minor amendments to the legislation.
That is another thing that is wrong with this. In such an important matter only 25 per cent of the members of this House will have the opportunity to take part, and the 25 per cent who can speak would not be allowed to make any meaningful amendments to the question.
There is no reason, no reason at all, for the government not to consult the opposition on this important issue.
Finally, the referendum fails to address significant proposed changes to the Canadian Elections Act that were recommended by the royal commission. One concerns spending limits. I certainly am one who feels that there must be spending limits, otherwise people with the money will be able to hire the best PR people and the best organizers, and then maybe it will be money that will change the results. It is important that we have limits

May 20, 1992

because it is only with limits that Canadians will perceive this referendum as being fair.
If it is perceived as being unfair by Canadians then the losing side will say: "Well, it was manipulated, it was bought". I feel very strongly that there must be spending limits.
I know that my time is running out. However, I want to repeat that I support the concept of a referendum. I feel that the referendum must be mandatory, not optional as is provided for in this legislation; it must include the principle of regional majorities or it is not fair, and there must be spending limits.
I have other concerns as well. However, in the limited time that I have those were the three points I wanted to mention.

Mr. Speaker, 12 years ago to the day, following the referendum in Quebec, I was standing there with the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister, Claude Ryan and all the others that had supported the no campaign. We were promised a renewed federalism. In 1982 with the patri-ation of the Constitution, English Canada got a renewed federalism, but Quebec was left on the sideline.
Following the election of the Liberal Party of Quebec in 1985, one of the first issues discussed at the National Assembly had to do with finding a common ground to allow Quebec to reintegrate the Canadian Federation with dignity.
That resulted in the Meech Lake accord, which had been ratified by ten premiers as well as the Prime Minister of the country. We know the outcome of this sad story: on June 23 1990, the Meech Lake accord died. Since then, we have spent practically two years talking about the Constitution in this House, while industries close down, thousands of people lose their jobs, our young people experience problems, and our old people are looking for security. We in this House try to destroy rather than build. Mr. Speaker, contrary to those who might claim that this destruction is caused by the Bloc Quebecois members, it is English Canada that has simply refused to allow Quebec to reintegrate the Canadian Constitution.
Now we are debating Bill C-81. This is a fraud; it is a diversion to create confusion, given the fact that it will be an empty consultive process that will cost Canadians and Quebecers some $110 million. This is ridiculous. It is ridiculous because it has no legal value. This referendum will not change anything; it will not solve any problems because people representing the government have told us that they do not want to hold a referendum; it is just in case.
We found that out today at the federal-provincial constitutional conference that is being held in Montreal. They waited to be in Montreal to create a common front of five anglophone provinces asking for an elected, equal and effective Senate. We know that Quebec is against that, as is Ontario, but what is worse is the fact that the same English provinces are telling Quebec that there will be no right of veto for Quebec or a distinct society as described in the Beaudoin-Dobbie report.
This is a far cry from the Meech Lake Accord, from the five small conditions that would have enabled Quebec to reintegrate the Canadian Constitution. However, Quebec is no longer interested in that stuff. We no longer talk about language, culture and the civil code. This is no longer what Quebec seeks. Indeed, the Liberal Party of Quebec approved the Allaire report during its congress in 1991. That report recommended 24 powers for Quebec: a major decentralization. On the other hand, Canada precisely wants to keep a strong central government. That is where the problem lies. We understand that in Quebec. We do not want to keep English Canada from continuing to have a strong central government. We agree on that. But we are also agree that Quebec wants to decentralize to the point of forming a country. The country that is missing within this Canada is the state of Quebec, next to it. We want friendly relations and exchanges. But from a political point of view, Quebec wants to choose its own laws. A while ago I was listening to some members who were calling us separatists. Maybe they should look at themselves in a mirror, Mr. Speaker. As a matter of fact, we should remind the hon. members who accuse us, members of the Bloc Quebecois, of being illegitimate, that all the Quebec members in this House
