That, in the opinion of this House, the government should amend the Canadian Security Intelligence Service Act (CSIS Act) to authorize the Security Intelligence Review Committee (SIRC) to review the operations of the Communications Security Establishment (CSE).
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to address this item of Private Members' Business which I consider a most important issue. I understand that other members of this House feel the same way.
The motion asks for the government to amend the Security Intelligence Service Act to authorize the Security Intelligence Review Committee to review the business affairs of CSE, the Communications Security Establishment.
This issue has been floating around this House for a couple of years now with virtually no adequate material response on the part of the government.
The first thing I want to do is describe the agency which, for all intents and purposes, is unchecked or unmonitored by Parliament or other external agencies within government.
This particular agency has a budget of about $250 million. I say "about" because no one in this House knows what the budget is other than, perhaps, two or three ministers who sit on the Privy Council Committee on Security and Intelligence.
The second thing we know is that it has about 850 employees, about, but we are not sure. We are also advised that approximately 1,100 Department of National Defence employees work in the endeavour.
What is the endeavour? It is twofold. The Communications Security Establishment provides information, advice and consultation to government departments on the security of their communications. That is internal-external security so that when communications are made
May 20, 1992

in any mode, they are secure and, hopefully, unmonitored by parties who might want to monitor them.
The second role, and this is the one I speak mostly to this evening, is that of signals intelligence gathering. This $250 million a year agency gathers communications signals, basically out of the air, not just in Canada but elsewhere in the world from its bases wherever it has access. We do not know where all those bases are for the same reason we were not told the budget or the number of employees or a lot of other things the agency does. We do know where the agency's office is located and we do know who the head of the agency is.
Before I go further I would like to give some credit, although I am a little sheepish about doing it. I have to give some credit to The Globe and Mail, not to the government, for investing a lot of time and hours in researching this Communications Security Establishment. Its series of articles on this by Mr. Peter Moon was quite a good series and provided yours truly with basically the only blueprint, the only collected set of information about this particular agency. That, I suggest to Canadians, should be an insult to them; not the good work of The Globe and Mail but the fact that Canada's Parliament does not have this information and cannot get it.
Why is Parliament interested? Let us review quickly the role of Parliament. In essence, there are books written about the role of Parliament but it boils down to a couple of basics. One of them is that the Crown, the government, does not tax the people without the consent of Parliament and, second, it does not spend the people's money without the consent of Parliament.
Parliament does other things in that role. That includes legislating, that is passing the laws that authorize the spending. Parliament also monitors government. Parliament is separate from government. It monitors in its committees and other processes what government does on behalf of Canada's citizens.
I want to point out that CSE, notwithstanding all the things that it does, bears no relation to any of those functions because there is no statute governing CSE. There is no statutory law that describes what CSE is or what it does. We will get into a bit more detail later as to
Private Members' Business
what CSE does. As well, there is no law or instrument that sets out the mandate for CSE. No one really knows precisely what CSE is mandated to do.
I am saying this from the floor of Parliament, whose job it is to know what government is doing. There is no specific accountability for its spending. I cannot determine what kind of money it spends. The $250 million figure that I just bounced before the House I think came from The Globe and Mail study because I cannot get it in any of the committees. It is simply not there.
For all the other reasons we have just discussed, there is no monitoring because CSE sits out there beyond the reach of most of the parliamentary scrutiny devices and monitoring devices. The bottom line is that there is no accountability by this agency for what it does and for what it spends. That is an unfortunate circumstance. I am hopeful that the process here in Parliament, which includes the debate on this motion, will provide a solution that is acceptable to the security and intelligence framework that we have in this country and which is acceptable to Parliament.
I have no doubt that the taxpayers, the people who pay the bills, are of the view that Parliament has to satisfy itself. We here in this House, all of the members, have to assure ourselves on behalf of our electors that this agency is operating within a law-there is not a law now-and that it is spending properly our tax dollars.
This signals intelligence gathering began during the last war. As far as I can ascertain, it was not until the year 1975 that there was any legal reference to it in government records. It is a pretty pitiful list of references. There is a series of three statutory orders which are expressed or articulated as subsidiary legislation of other statutes. I think one is the Treasury Board, another is the Financial Administration Act and the other is the Public Service Employment Act, all basically exempting this particular agency, which had come into being, from any scrutiny under those agencies.
Just so that you know this is non-partisan, the government that did that was a Liberal government in 1975. There has basically been no change. It could have been any government. The environment in the 1950s, the 1960s and the 1970s was I think very much different in terms of civil liberties than the environment is today. I

hope it is different in relation to government accountability.
One of the problems at CSE, one of the reasons why we find it difficult in Parliament to monitor it, is that the government, probably not by design but just by historical evolution, has permitted the agency's existence to divide into two separate pieces. They are as follows:
The agency in 1975 was moved from the National Research Council where it must have been a "project" for many years. It moved to the Department of National Defence and it exists there today as a section of the Department of National Defence. Presumably, there is a colonel or a general who, I believe, is unnamed who has administrative responsibility for this. That is, financial and administrative responsibility lies with the Department of National Defence.
However, who controls the policy and operations-and the real word here is operations-the day-to-day functioning, the things it does? The answer to that is the Privy Council Office. The Privy Council Office is basically the Prime Minister's Office. It is the office of public servants who run the Prime Minister's function in this country.
As far as I know, the Privy Council Office does not account to any parliamentary committee, especially in terms of operations which they call top secret, top secret umbra-we will not go into too much jargon here-or simply secret.
Little guys like us in this House of Commons probably would never get within a hundred feet of that secret or top secret information, most of which we do not have to get close to anyway. But when we are monitoring we have to have the ability to find out what is going on.
What is my concern about CSE? What is our concern in Parliament? Is it just a spending and monitoring issue? No, it is not. In particular, this agency has the comprehensive ability to eavesdrop anywhere it wants. I am talking about total comprehensive eavesdropping, principally based on eavesdropping of electromagnetic signals or transmissions.
Anything that moves and creates a pattern is ascertainable by this agency, by its net. It has an intelligence-gathering net. There is an additional wrinkle in this which I will get to later. But all electronic signals, everything that moves in Canada, is trappable, receivable, nettable. All phone conversations, all fax machine transmissions, all radio frequencies, even those that are encoded and enciypted, are trapped or trappable within the net used world-wide by CSE and its brother or sister components in other countries.
This is going on right now. They could be listening to me right now, quite possibly. They certainly could. This is certainly carried on with our internal monitoring system. Now they probably do not want to listen to me, but they might be. They have a net that is capable of doing that. They have a net world-wide capable of picking up this information and screening it through one of only three CRAY supercomputers in this country. That is a very expensive piece of machinery, but it basically is able to analyze all of these signals and, I suppose, to read them using key words, and to draw out those which it wishes to retain. It puts them into its own coded retaining language. These are then submitted to further analysis in Canada, the U.K., the U.S.A., Australia, or in other countries.
That is what they are capable of doing. That is why we are concerned that this agency is not monitored.
I want to mention the problem of reciprocal exchange agreements between CSE and other countries. The United States National Security Agency is perfectly capable of listening to what I am saying now. If it wants to listen, it does it. It has satellite transmission capability as well as satellite networks and earth transmission networks, and CSE is a part of it. It is not illegal. It is listening from up in space or some place else. It is doing it from Buffalo. It does not matter.
If it is listening, and it is capable of doing it, it takes the data to Maryland or West Virginia to the National Security Agency where it is coded. If Canada wants that information, CSE can get it. It runs it through the super computer checking for key words. It sees somebody is talking about CSE. All of that can happen. The Austra-
May 20, 1992

lians can do it, the British can do it. It is that trading, that subcontracting capability that we are not able to monitor.
We do not know whether data that we are using in Canada is obtained legally, illegally in other countries, whether it is eavesdropping, whether it is a breach of Canadian statutes, U.K. statues, Australian statutes, French statutes. They are getting the data and they are using it, we think for a good purpose. We know it is for a good purpose. It is for our national security. That covers a lot of territory.
Now that we know it is out there and the capability is there, all of our privacy is therefore at risk. We are not monitoring in this country.
What has Parliament said about this? A couple of years ago Parliament did a five-year review of the CSIS statute, the Canadian Security Intelligence Service Act. I served on that committee, as did two or three other members in this House here now. They are here because they are concerned about it. They had a number of things to say about this.
First, they wanted to note the capability and they ended up by making a recommendation. Even though CSE was not part of CSIS, it gives data information to CSIS. That was confirmed. The committee recommended that Parliament formally establish the CSE by statute, which does not exist now, and second, establish the Security Intelligence Review Committee, which already exists to oversee CSIS, as the body responsible for monitoring, reviewing and reporting to Parliament on the activities of CSE concerning its compliance with the laws of Canada. That was the recommended solution.
The recommendation was not adopted. I want to refer to the government's response to that report. It admitted the problem. I do not accept the statement that "a broad accountability system for CSIS is in place". I am not going to go through the details. It is not there. I am telling this House as a member that the accountability is not there.
Even if there is some Public Service accountability, which I am not familiar with, there certainly is not in this House. "Nevertheless, such an accountability system can always be improved and the government has been considering providing the Minister of National Defence with some additional capacity for review of CSE. Once the decision is taken-", et cetera. There is no mention of Parliament, no mention of parliamentary accountability.
Private Members' Business
The Security Intelligence Review Committee made reference to it in its 1991 report. The former chairman of the Security Intelligence Review Committee, Mr. Ron Atkey, stated recently in an interview: "We need a system that will provide some accountability and some assurance to you as a private citizen that you are not being abused". To date, we do not have that.
The government's response to that committee was inadequate. It did nothing. Members were so dissatisfied with the response of that report that from all sides they created a parliamentary subcommittee to deal with national security.
Someone has said that CSE is accountable to the general law. That is true, but they are in the same area that the RCMP was in 15 years ago. Mounties who were sworn to uphold the law broke the law with the bam burning incident some 15 years ago.
If the Mounties were able to break the law, if they fell into that trap, how much more likely is it that civilians not sworn in the same way would also break the law? I am not accusing anybody. It is a problem. I want to encourage this House to adopt this motion. I want to make Canadians aware this is a matter of very serious and important unfinished business, and that a statute and legislation are necessary.
Canadians must have this degree of accountability. They should insist upon it. I am hoping the House will adopt this motion.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Monique Tardif (Parliamentary Secretary to Solicitor General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Solicitor General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak to this motion concerning the role of the Security Intelligence Review Committee, also known as the SIRC within the national security system.
In 1984, the Canadian Security Intelligence Service (CSIC) Act and the Security Offences Act established a new legislative framework to govern Canada's national security system.
The new legislation was designed to create a balanced and accountable system for the protection of Canada's national security interests and the preservation of the democratic way of life of its people. It provided the main legislative framework for the national security system, assigning security intelligence to CSIS, and confirmed

May 20, 1992
Private Members' Business
the security enforcement and the protective security mandate of the RCMP.
Embodied in the legislation was a set of interlocking principles to shape and guide the operation of the system and each principle can be associated with one of its major participants.
The legislation incorporated a clear mandate and strict controls of the activities of the new service. The inclusion of ministerial oversight and sophisticated review mechanisms ensured that the service would be effective and that the rights of individuals would be respected. Balance was a distinguishing feature of the legislation.
The need to protect national security was balanced by respect for individual rights and freedoms. The need to provide the service with sufficient powers to produce effective security intelligence was balanced by statutory controls and policy direction.
The need for CSIS to employ certain intrusive techniques was balanced by the requirement for prior authorization by a minister of the Crown and the Federal Court. The need for secrecy was balanced by ministerial accountability and informed independent review.
The national security system assigned specific and distinct mandates to CSIS and the RCMP. The service's primary mandate is to be found in two provisions of the CSIS act: the definition of "threats to the security of Canada", and the description of the service's duty to collect, analyse and retain information and intelligence on "threats to the security of Canada".
In order to fulfill its mandate the service undertakes counter-terrorism and counter-intelligence investigations of various types and duration.
The CSIS mandate is conditioned by the limits and controls specified in the act, by ministerial directions, and by the service's own operational policies and procedures. Certain powers employed by the service are subject to the requirement to obtain a judicial warrant.
In view of the complexity of CSIS activities and the importance of securing public confidence in the integrity of the system, the CSIS act provides for an independent external review body, the SIRC, reporting to Parliament through the Solicitor General on the activities of the service. The act also establishes the function of the inspector general to conduct independent internal reviews of the service for the Solicitor General
Like other government departments and agencies,
CSIS is required to pursue its objectives with full respect for the law including the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Legislation governing the creation of a security intelligence agency has a special need for a policy framework, if there is to be public confidence in how the agency operates. Ministerial direction helps to ensure that the Solicitor General, who is accountable to Parliament, is the linchpin in the legal and policy framework.
The principles of ministerial control and accountability are central to Canadian parliamentary democracy. The CSIS Act ensured that the minister would have full knowledge and power of direction over the policies, operations and management of CSIS and also supplies the minister with the means to control and guide the service.
The function of the inspector general forms an integral part of the over-all accountability process. The CSIS Act established the inspector general's reporting role to the minister.
The terms of the act assign the inspector general a review and a monitoring function with respect to CSIS, and no information other than cabinet confidences may be withheld on any grounds.
By serving the minister directly, the inspector general maintains a measure of distance from the minister's policy and operational advisors in the ministry secretariat.
Canadian are protected by limitations in the CSIS mandate and the scope of prescribed activities of the service, by the conditions of the warrant process and the complaint and review processes provided in the act.
In the performance of its duties and functions, CSIS has no authority to counter or deter threats to the security of Canada. Furthermore, information is to be collected only to the extent that it is "strictly necessary". Investigations are to be initiated only when suspicions are based on "reasonable grounds", and the investigations themselves are to be conducted in a reasonable manner.
May 20, 1992

The definition of threats to the security of Canada excludes lawful advocacy, protest or dissent, unless carried on in conjuction with any of the activities referred to in the CSIS act.
Judicial authorization is required for the exercise of the most intrusive powers of CSIS and is granted only after a rigorous internal process of approval is completed, including consultation with the Deputy Solicitor General and the approval of the Solicitor General.
The Solicitor General conveys his views to the service through written ministerial directions and his intentions through the approval processes, for example in approving warrant applications, and in regular meetings with the director.
Assistance to the Secretary of State for External Affairs and the Minister of National Defence in the collection of foreign intelligence excludes investigation of Canadian citizens and permanent residents and corporations, and must occur within Canada.
The director of CSIS is required by law to report on illegal activity of any member of the service in the performance of his duties.
This represents a brief discussion of the system governing Canada's national security. A recent review by the special committee found that it is basically sound, has served the nation well and should be preserved.
Mr. Speaker, let me now turn to the role of SIRC, which is an innovative and important component of the national security system established by the CSIS act.
Responsibility for this independent external review function was given to the Security Intelligence Review Committee (SIRC), a non-partisan committee of privy councillors which reports to Parliament through the Solicitor General.
SIRS'S review role is a cornerstone of the accountability framework established by the CSIS act. SIRC has a mandate to review the propriety of CSIS activities, with emphasis on the delicate balance between national security and individual freedoms.
Private Members' Business
Given SIRC's importance as presently constituted, the government does not agree with the proposed statutory amendment which would expand SIRC's role. In the government's view, it would have the effect of either diffusing SIRC's functions with respect to CSIS or diminishing ministerial accountability.
The SIRC, created in large part to act as Parliament's surrogate in the sensitive area of security intelligence, consists of five part-time members who are privy councillors but must not be sitting members of either the House of Commons or the Senate, and is assisted by a small staff of researchers.
The members of SIRC see their part-time status as a great advantage which assists them in maintaining their independence and objectivity. By retaining their chosen career as their main professional activity, they avoid becoming captives of the system.
Finally, through daily accountability in the House of Commons, supplementary and main estimates process, standing committee hearings, special committees (terrorism), the subcommittee on national security, the tabling of SIRC and other special reports, and parliamentary review of the legislation, Parliament is the ultimate review body.
Mr. Speaker, this illustrates that the CSIS act, which created SIRC's review role, was well thought out. The special committee, when it reviewed its provisions and operation, found the CSIS act basically sound. As presently constituted, SIRC well serves its intended purpose.

Mr. Speaker, we indeed live in strange times. Just last week in the United Kingdom the British Prime Minister admitted that MI-6 actually existed when it was in fact founded over a century ago.
The motion we have before us relates to a Canadian institution, the Communications Security Establishment, which has been in existence for about half a century, perhaps not under that name. Parliament still has absolutely no control over that body, and for all practical purposes it does not exist either. In fact, we do not have anything in the estimates, they are hidden in the Department of National Defence estimates.

May 20, 1992
Private Members' Business
I just had the ordeal of listening for 15 minutes to a speech that had absolutely no relevance to this motion. A speech on CSIS and SIRC was relevant to the debates of spring of 1984, but of absolutely no relevance to the debate this evening. I do not think the parliamentary secretary even made a passing reference to CSE. She certainly said nothing about its operations.
I want to congratulate my colleague, the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River, for bringing forward this motion this evening because I think it is very timely. It is timely not only because it concerns a highly secretive information-gathering agency which has no parliamentary responsibility. It is about the accountability of a secret organization. That is what we are discussing and debating tonight.
In 1992, when Canada is not at war with anyone and no one is plotting war on Canada, we have a secret agency that can listen in on virtually any kind of electronic transmission anywhere in Canada, indeed anywhere in continental North America. We do not even know how far it goes beyond continental North America.
The Communications Security Establishment, which originated some 50 years ago in the National Research Council, I think it was part of its communications directorate, has remained under the cloak of secrecy ever since. The reason it has is because it is a secret organization and therefore it is involved in secret activity. That secret activity is listening in on all the electronic communications of foreign embassies in Ottawa or consulates in Montreal, Toronto or Vancouver or wherever they happen to be. It listens in on all kinds of government traffic. It is also responsible for the security of government information and government documents. It is really the security agency for Parliament Hill, and perhaps I should say for cabinet, the Privy Council Office and the office of the Prime Minister.
I would not object to that if it was simply a security agency of government to protect information within the Government of Canada from foreign eavesdropping. If that were its only activity, I would not be standing up this evening and demanding greater accountability because I can understand that part of its operations.
Every prudent government in the world has that kind of security or at least attempts to have that kind of security. I am not denigrating the capability or the expertise of CSE. I have no way of doing that because I do not know anything about it. As a parliamentarian I am not allowed to know anything about CSE. I am precluded not by law or statute but by some arrangement within the PCO. On that part of it I simply have to stand back and ask like any other citizen: "I have no right to know, therefore what can I do?"
I can stand here on my feet tonight and verbally blast away at the government and say: "Look, that part of CSE's operation may be acceptable in its secrecy, but the other activities of CSE, that is the electronic eavesdropping on foreign embassies, the electronic eavesdropping on citizens, not necessarily of this country but in the United States, for example"-and I will get to that in a moment-"and CSE's ability to tap into sources south of the border with respect to electronic eavesdropping in Canada should be scrutinized".
Now the member who moved this motion said earlier that it has the capability, and I agree with this, of listening in on virtually every fax machine transmission, every telephone call, every cellular telephone communication. Anything of an electronic nature can be tapped into.
We are told by the minister and by his senior personnel in the Solicitor General's office that CSE does not operate in any illegal manner, that is it does not collect information in this country on Canadian citizens in an illegal manner, in a manner contrary to the Criminal Code of Canada. I will accept that argument because the National Security Agency in the United States assures American congressmen and senators that it does not eavesdrop on American citizens contrary to their Bill of Rights.
But there is no law in North America prohibiting NSA from getting in touch with the CSE in Canada and saying: "I want you to keep track electronically of so-and-so resident in South Dakota or Alabama". CSE can do that and pass on information to the NSA, therefore circumventing any American law. The National Security Agency, buddy-buddy that is with the CSE, can do exactly the same thing and eavesdrop on Canadian citizens, contrary to Canadian law but circumventing that law.
May 20, 1992

That is the part of CSE that disturbs me. That is the part of CSE that I would like to know a little more about. I would like to know whether or not in fact the sourcing of its information, whether or not it comes from the Americans, the British or the Australians, is done in a manner that is in accordance with our rights here in this country, with our Criminal Code and with our charter. That is what I want to know.
As far as I can determine there are no legislative safeguards. There are no oversight safeguards. There is no committee or subcommittee of this House that has any jurisdiction over CSE. We cannot put a question on CSE in this House in Question Period either to the Solicitor General or to the Minister of National Defence. He will get up and answer that because of the national security involved with that agency he is unable to answer the member's question. We cannot put questions in committee. We can ask the Minister of National Defence to appear but we know ahead of time that he or she will not answer questions on the CSE.
This motion, if passed or adopted, would mandate SIRC to have the same oversight power or responsibility with respect to CSE as it has with CSIS, but SIRC does not have that mandate. The government will not give SIRC that mandate.
We need a couple of things here. I agree with the motion completely. The Security Intelligence Review Committee should include the Communications Security Establishment as part of its mandate. It should be the citizens' oversight committee for CSE just as it is for the Canadian Security Intelligence Service.
But I would go further than that. I would mandate CSE's existence by statute. I would bring in a bill. It would be thoroughly debated in this House at all stages. It would go to a committee. The special committee has already looked at this at least in part, but now we could devote our entire resources to CSE. We would come up with a bill just as we did with CSIS. Therefore it would be statutorily established instead of tucked away somewhere by tradition, by some kind of secret arrangement within the Privy Council Office for only the eyes and ears of only two, three or four top public servants to have any control over or any counsel over the operations of CSE.
Private Members' Business
We live in a democracy. We are not at war. We are under no stress. Surely CSE should come under parliamentary mandate. It should be statutorily established by an act of Parliament. SIRC, as stated in this motion, should have the right to oversee its operations as a citizens' committee watch-dog on the Communications Security Establishment.
I see my time is up.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to join in this debate. As a member of the special committee that studied CSIS with my other friends who are in the House, I did agree and sign the report that said that CSE should have its own legislated mandate and that SIRC should be mandated to oversee CSE.
My friends from Scarborough-Rouge River and Brant have gone into detail on the Communications Security Establishment and what we know. Certainly the minister has primary responsibility. That is our system as it exists today. In that regard the CSE is apparently under the Department of National Defence. The Minister of National Defence would have authority over that particular agency and a reporting function to Parliament in that regard.
I would like to say there is no indication that anybody's civil liberties have been offended by CSE. Therefore, why are we bringing this particular matter forward? Why was this motion brought forward? We saw, as was indicated in the early 1980s, that the RCMP security establishment, sworn to uphold the law, did run afoul of the law in regard to national security matters.
As a result it was decided that the security service would be made a civilian agency. It would be given its own legislative mandate. Certain checks would be put in place in order to defend the civil liberties of Canadians. Those were outlined very well by the parliamentary secretary and included SIRC, the Security Intelligence Review Committee, as well as the inspector general.
We found in our review of CSIS that these organizations have functioned well and have protected the civil liberties of Canadians. We looked at other areas of the security establishment in this country. We understand there is security apparatus within the Department of External Affairs, within the transport department and with CSE, to name a few.

May 20, 1992
Private Members' Business
To make sure that the civil liberties of Canadians were protected and that we did not have any incidents where those civil liberties were offended and as a result there would a great uproar in Parliament, it was decided by the committee that we would recommend that CSE be given its own legislative mandate and, since SIRC had worked so well in overseeing CSIS, that SIRC be mandated to oversee CSE as well.
CSIS in the act, as was pointed out by the parliamentary secretary, has its own legislative mandate in regard to threats to the security of Canada. Surely the CSE could be given a similar legislative mandate as a standard by which it can be judged in its picking up of the various electromagnetic signals and which it would take into consideration.
It is my belief that there are memorandums of understanding between CSIS and CSE, so there is some exchange of information. Obviously the memorandum itself is secret and should remain so, but the mere fact of a memorandum of understanding indicates that there is an agreement as to what information will be turned over to CSIS in certain circumstances.
It is not out of the question for people who have the responsibility, as we do here in Parliament, to want to know what that information is. We should be able to get at that particular information. We should know in general terms what the budget of the organization is so that we can fulfil our oversight function, and also so that we can ensure that the civil liberties of Canadians are protected.
Our first choice would have been a model similar to the United States. When we were doing our study on CSIS we found that in the United States all the security intelligence agencies are overseen by two congressional committees, one of the Senate and one of the House of Representatives. They have access to all the information in regard to all the security establishments in the United States, including their NSA.
We in Canada did not go that route in overseeing our security intelligence service. We decided we would do it through the Security Intelligence Review Committee, made up of Privy Council members who were mandated to actually take the place of Parliament because it is a secret organization. Obviously it is important to the security of our country. They were to take the place of Parliament, and that is why the Privy Councillors were put in this particular position.
We on the committee accept that concept. We found that it was working well. As was mentioned, the Security Intelligence Review Committee does look at what CSIS does. It delves into various matters to ensure that the civil liberties of Canadians are protected, and we can see that in its annual report. Obviously that has an effect on CSIS and it makes sure that the civil liberties of Canadians are taken care of and are not abused.
Our thinking on the committee was that we should put all the security intelligence apparatus under some form of oversight, that includes the other ones I mentioned and would be found in the report.
We feel there was a reaction in the early 1980s to what had gone on in the RCMP security service. CSIS was established and the model is working. Now in a time when we do not have a great crisis we should look at our entire security establishment and establish oversight in the other areas as well.
CSE is an organization shrouded in a great deal of secrecy, rightfully so. However, what is occurring there? There are no indications that there have ever been any civil liberties that have been abused by this particular organization, but we do not know. As members of Parliament we would like to be reassured that no aspect of our security intelligence apparatus in this country is offending any of the civil liberties of Canadians.
SIRC has worked well in terms of the oversight of CSIS. We suggested that it be given additional responsibility and its oversight be extended to CSE. I can understand the argument that SIRC has worked well on a part-time basis. One of the things we were concerned about in our study was that SIRC had not been co-opted by CSIS. We found no indication of that.
One of the reasons we felt that had occurred was because of the part-time nature of its oversight function. If it is felt that this would be too much of a burden for SIRC and would take away from the part-time nature of its job then why not create another body similar to SIRC to oversee CSE. Privy Councillors can do the job in this case also.
My personal preference would be to put that entire oversight function within a parliamentary committee. We have done that to a certain extent with the subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General which we have formed.
May 20, 1992

If we are going to proceed on the basis of the SIRC model, which has worked well, I would urge that we go ahead with a legislative mandate for CSE, set out what it is that it is collecting and in what terms, such as threats to the security of Canada, a similar definition as is put in the CSIS Act that we could compare it against and make sure that is what this particular organization is collecting.
There may be an argument that it cannot get the co-operation of the National Security Agency in the United States. We heard that one from CSIS when SIRC was established. SIRC went to the United States and found that once the initial barriers were broken down, it could co-operate and the Americans were satisfied with the security intelligence agency.
In conclusion, I would support a legislative mandate for CSE. I would like to see SIRC or a SIRC-like body set up in order to protect the civil liberties of Canadians in regard to CSE but not only in CSE, in every aspect of the security apparatus here in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise and speak on this particular motion. I had the pleasure of serving on the review committee that studied CSIS.
The motion of my colleague for Scarborough-Rouge River is an excellent one and really gets to the heart of the matter. He is being very skilful in what he is doing because all of these spy agencies, if you can use that terminology, should be included under a review or oversight function. He is starting with CSE which is the more serious one and which does not even have a parliamentary mandate. I am sure as time goes along and after the government sees the wisdom of this motion and enacts it, we will see other agencies fall within the ambit of a review agency such as SIRC.
On that review committee of which I had the pleasure to serve, we had a recommendation. I believe it is recommendation 87. I quote: "The committee recommends that Parliament formally establish CSE by statute and establish SIRC as the body responsible for monitoring, reviewing and reporting to Parliament on the activities of CSE concerning its compliance with the laws of Canada".
Private Members' Business
That was an excellent recommendation but the government chose not to deal with that particular recommendation. There were a number of recommendations in our report that the government refused to deal with. It only adopted one or one and a half recommendations which is unfortunate. Ron Atkey, who was the chairman of SIRC, gave a very interesting radio interview in March 1991 in which he talked about the recommendations which we came up with as parliamentarians and submitted to Parliament. I again quote because it is illustrative of what is going on here:
None of these recommendations were earth shattering. Why were they rejected? The explanation may relate as much to the malaise in our parliamentary system. It seems there is simply not the time and inclination to debate important legislation in a non-partisan way these days. It is also clear that the government wanted to avoid at any cost the commitment to introduce legislative changes. How convenient for CSIS which really never wanted to limit itself to investigating terrorism and espionage.
This little part is really illustrative.
And wasn't this just super for the Communications Security Establishment, that huge vacuum cleaner in the sky which has frightening capacity to invade the privacy of Canadians in a variety of ways but which has no legal mandate and which is not accountable to anyone except to the Department of National Defence and the Privy Council Office, the principal users of the data gathered.
That is very illustrative. There is the head of SIRC as he then was saying this is a very serious situation. This was a simple recommendation which came forward in our study. It is the same recommendation which the member for Scarborough-Rouge River is putting forward to Parliament again. That is to put some oversight, some control, some protection on the privacy of individuals. CSE is aptly described as the huge vacuum cleaner in the sky which is scooping up information all over the place. And we have no control over it, no say as to what is going to happen.
Both Mr. Atkey and Mr. Jean-Jacques Blais are no longer on SIRC, but when they were, they made some comments. There was an article in The Globe and Mail in June, 1991. I quote again from Jean-Jacques Blais who said: "My knowledge of the Communications Security Establishment was very superficial indeed when I was minister of defence." Ilien later on he says: "-and I am sure that the minister of defence today has no better knowledge relating to CSE than the Solicitor General had prior to the establishment of the review process."

May 20, 1992
Private Members' Business
So, here we are again, looking at two people who had an intimate knowledge of what is going on with CSE and an intimate knowledge of over-all data collection, and as a lot of people call it, the spy agencies that are here in Canada. They all say that they know nothing about what is going on with CSE. There is no parliamentary mandate; it was established by an Order in Council. It is not overseen by Parliament or by SIRC.
Now everyone knows the review committee said that in addition to SIRC there should also be a parliamentary review involved. We went so far as to see a subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General established for that purpose.
I am sure everyone realizes there is a lot of work in these committees. We do not set these committees up frivolously. We do not set them up just to have another name or a title. This particular committee that did the review and the subcommittee that is working now are hard-working committees designed, quite frankly, to protect Canadian privacy. That has to be something that is fundamental to this country.
Right now in private conversations in homes or businesses or in any organization, that huge vacuum cleaner in the sky could be scooping all of that information up and utilizing it some day, putting it in a file or a data bank and storing it away so that some day that could be used against someone. That is fundamentally wrong. The idea of having a spy agency doing all of the things that have to be done, the idea of data collection in order to protect Canada is absolutely essential.
We are into all kinds of arrangements with a number of countries in sharing information and protecting one another. There is nothing wrong with that. But as Canadians we have to be satisfied. I feel I have to be satisfied as a parliamentarian that these agencies are not carrying out any abuses, and that the work they are doing is the proper work.
That is where SIRC comes in. It can do in private that type of research and report to Parliament and say: "Yes, CSE is functioning properly. No, it has not taken any intrusive steps without proper reasons and without going
before the proper organizations or courts to get the necessary permission to carry out these intrusions." All those sorts of things would then be laid before Parliament and we would have an opportunity to look at them and decide that we need not worry, everything is working fine.
Instead we have a situation in which we have an organization without a parliamentary mandate, without being overseen by Parliament or SIRC, now functioning in our Canadian society and continuing to monitor everything that we are saying. As a former great leader of the Liberal Party said, it is "interfering in what is going on in the bedrooms of the nation".
Quite frankly, I can tell by the look on your face, Mr. Speaker, that is a concern to you and it is a concern to us on this side. That is why my colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River is bringing forward this motion which will see the necessary protection to Canadian privacy if it is adopted.
I hope that the government will see the benefit of an all-party committee's recommendation that this be done. I heard my colleague opposite talk about the same types of things that we are talking about on this side. It is unanimous among parliamentarians. We need the executive branch to deal with this and make sure that Canadians are protected.
